translations.idiomatic: The feudal lords got wind of their scheme and informed Xiang Yu.

sentences.zh: 項羽乃召黥布、蒲將軍計曰：「秦吏卒尚眾，其心不服，至關中不聽，事必危，不如擊殺之，而獨與章邯、長史欣、都尉翳入秦。」

translations.literal: Xiang Yu then summoned Ying Bu and General Pu to consult, saying: 'The Qin officers and soldiers are still numerous, their hearts not submissive, when we reach Guanzhong they will not obey, the matter will certainly be dangerous, it is better to attack and kill them, and alone with Zhang Han, Chief Clerk Xin, and Commandant Yi enter Qin.'
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu then summoned Ying Bu and General Pu for a conference: 'The Qin officers and soldiers are still numerous and their loyalties uncertain. When we reach Guanzhong, they may not obey orders, making the situation dangerous. It would be better to attack and kill them, then proceed into Qin with only Zhang Han, Chief Clerk Xin, and Commandant Yi.'

sentences.zh: 於是楚軍夜擊阬秦卒二十餘萬人新安城南。

translations.literal: Thereupon the Chu army at night attacked and buried alive more than two hundred thousand Qin soldiers south of Xin'an city.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon the Chu army attacked by night and massacred over two hundred thousand Qin soldiers south of Xin'an city.

translations.literal: They arrived at Xin'an. The feudal lords' officials and soldiers, who at different times had been conscripted to garrison and pass through Qin territory, were treated very poorly by Qin's officials and soldiers. Now that the Qin army had surrendered to the feudal lords, the feudal lords' officials and soldiers, riding on victory, often enslaved and used them, lightly breaking and humiliating the Qin officials and soldiers. The Qin officials and soldiers often whispered among themselves: 'General Zhang and the others deceived us into surrendering to the feudal lords. If we can now enter the passes and break Qin, that would be very good; If we cannot, the feudal lords will capture us and go east. Qin will certainly execute all our parents, wives, and children.' The feudal lords secretly heard of their plot and told Xiang Yu. Xiang Yu then summoned Qing Bu and General Pu to consult, saying: 'The Qin officials and soldiers are still numerous. Their hearts do not submit. When we reach Guanzhong they will not obey. This will certainly be dangerous. It is better to strike and kill them, and go alone with Zhang Han, Chief Clerk Xin, and Commandery Captain Yi to enter Qin.' Therefore the Chu army struck at night and buried alive more than two hundred thousand Qin soldiers south of Xin'an city.

sentences.zh: 行略定秦地。

translations.literal: Marching and raiding, they pacified Qin territory.
translations.idiomatic: As they marched, they conquered and pacified the lands of Qin.

sentences.zh: 函谷關有兵守關，不得入。

translations.literal: Hangu Pass had troops guarding the pass, they could not enter.
translations.idiomatic: Hangu Pass was defended by troops, so they could not enter.

sentences.zh: 又聞沛公已破咸陽，項羽大怒，使當陽君等擊關。

translations.literal: He also heard that the Duke of Pei had already taken Xianyang, Xiang Yu greatly angered, sent Lord Dangyang and others to attack the pass.
translations.idiomatic: He also learned that the Duke of Pei had already captured Xianyang. Xiang Yu flew into a rage and sent Lord Dangyang and others to attack the pass.

sentences.zh: 項羽遂入，至于戲西。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu then entered, reaching west of Xi.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu then entered the pass and reached the area west of Xi.

sentences.zh: 沛公軍霸上，未得與項羽相見。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei's army was at Bashang, he had not yet been able to meet with Xiang Yu.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei's army was encamped at Bashang. He had not yet been able to meet with Xiang Yu.

sentences.zh: 沛公左司馬曹無傷使人言於項羽曰：「沛公欲王關中，使子嬰為相，珍寶盡有之。」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei's left commander Cao Wushang sent someone to speak to Xiang Yu saying: 'The Duke of Pei wishes to rule Guanzhong as king, make Zi Ying his chancellor, and possess all the precious treasures.'
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei's left commander Cao Wushang sent a messenger to Xiang Yu: 'The Duke of Pei wants to become king of Guanzhong, appoint Zi Ying as his chancellor, and claim all the precious treasures for himself.'

sentences.zh: 項羽大怒，曰：「旦日饗士卒，為擊破沛公軍！」

translations.literal: Xiang Yu greatly angered, said: 'Tomorrow feast the soldiers, in order to attack and defeat the Duke of Pei's army!'
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu flew into a rage: 'Tomorrow we'll feast the troops, then attack and crush the Duke of Pei's army!'

sentences.zh: 當是時，項羽兵四十萬，在新豐鴻門，沛公兵十萬，在霸上。

translations.literal: At this time, Xiang Yu's troops were four hundred thousand, at Hongmen in Xinfeng, the Duke of Pei's troops were one hundred thousand, at Bashang.
translations.idiomatic: At this juncture, Xiang Yu commanded four hundred thousand troops at Hongmen in Xinfeng, while the Duke of Pei had one hundred thousand troops at Bashang.

sentences.zh: 范增說項羽曰：「沛公居山東時，貪於財貨，好美姬。

translations.literal: Fan Zeng advised Xiang Yu saying: 'When the Duke of Pei lived in Shandong, he was greedy for wealth and goods, fond of beautiful women.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Zeng advised Xiang Yu: 'When the Duke of Pei lived east of the mountains, he was greedy for riches and fond of beautiful women.'

sentences.zh: 今入關，財物無所取，婦女無所幸，此其志不在小。

translations.literal: Now entering the passes, he takes no wealth or goods, shows no interest in women, his ambitions are not small.
translations.idiomatic: Now that he's entered the passes, he takes no riches and shows no interest in women. His ambitions are far from small.

sentences.zh: 吾令人望其氣，皆為龍虎，成五采，此天子氣也。

translations.literal: I sent people to observe his aura, it was all dragons and tigers, forming the five colors, this is the aura of a Son of Heaven.
translations.idiomatic: I had men observe his vapors. They form dragons and tigers in five colors. This is the aura of an emperor.

sentences.zh: 急擊勿失。」

translations.literal: Strike quickly, do not let him escape.'
translations.idiomatic: Attack immediately before it's too late.'

translations.literal: As they marched, they raided and pacified Qin territory. Hangu Pass had troops guarding it. They could not enter. They then heard that Liu Bang had already broken Xianyang. Xiang Yu was greatly angered. He had Lord Dangyang and others strike the pass. Xiang Yu then entered and arrived west of Xi. Liu Bang's army was at Bashang. He had not yet been able to meet with Xiang Yu. Liu Bang's left adjutant Cao Wushang sent people to speak to Xiang Yu, saying: 'Liu Bang wishes to rule Guanzhong as king, make Zi Ying his chancellor, and possess all the precious treasures.' Xiang Yu was greatly angered and said: 'Tomorrow I will feast the soldiers, then strike and break Liu Bang's army!' At this time, Xiang Yu had four hundred thousand troops at Hongmen in Xinfeng. Liu Bang had one hundred thousand troops at Bashang. Fan Zeng advised Xiang Yu, saying: 'When Liu Bang resided in Shandong, he was greedy for wealth and goods, fond of beautiful women. Now he has entered the passes but taken no wealth or goods, favored no women. His ambitions are not small. I had people observe his aura. It was all dragon and tiger, forming the five colors. This is the aura of a Son of Heaven. Strike quickly. Do not lose this opportunity.'

sentences.zh: 楚左尹項伯者，項羽季父也，素善留侯張良。

translations.literal: The Chu Left Minister Xiang Bo was Xiang Yu's youngest uncle, he had long been on good terms with Marquis Liu Zhang Liang.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Bo, Chu's Left Minister and Xiang Yu's youngest uncle, had long been close friends with Zhang Liang, Marquis of Liu.

sentences.zh: 張良是時從沛公，項伯乃夜馳之沛公軍，私見張良，具告以事，欲呼張良與俱去。

translations.literal: Zhang Liang at this time was following the Duke of Pei, Xiang Bo then rode at night to the Duke of Pei's army, privately met with Zhang Liang, fully informed him of the matters, wished to call Zhang Liang to leave together with him.
translations.idiomatic: At this time Zhang Liang was serving the Duke of Pei. Xiang Bo rode through the night to the Duke of Pei's camp and met privately with Zhang Liang. He told him everything and wanted to take Zhang Liang away with him.

sentences.zh: 曰：「毋從俱死也。」

translations.literal: Said: 'Do not follow and die together.'
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'Don't follow me to your death.'

sentences.zh: 張良曰：「臣為韓王送沛公，沛公今事有急，亡去不義，不可不語。」

translations.literal: Zhang Liang said: 'Your servant escorted the Duke of Pei for the King of Han, the Duke of Pei now has urgent matters, to flee would be unrighteous, I cannot not inform him.'
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang said: 'I was sent by the King of Han to escort the Duke of Pei. The Duke of Pei is now in grave danger. It would be dishonorable to flee without warning him.'

sentences.zh: 良乃入，具告沛公。

translations.literal: Liang then entered, fully informed the Duke of Pei.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang entered and told the Duke of Pei everything.

sentences.zh: 沛公大驚，曰：「為之柰何？」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei greatly startled, said: 'What can be done about it?'
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei was shocked: 'What shall we do?'

sentences.zh: 張良曰：「誰為大王為此計者？」

translations.literal: Zhang Liang said: 'Who devised this plan for Your Majesty?'
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang asked: 'Who gave you this advice?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「鯫生說我曰『距關，毋內諸侯，秦地可盡王也』。

translations.literal: Said: 'A petty man advised me saying "Bar the passes, do not admit the feudal lords, and Qin territory can all be ruled as king".'
translations.idiomatic: He replied: 'A small-minded man advised me: "Block the passes and don't let the feudal lords in. Then you can rule all Qin territory as king."'

sentences.zh: 故聽之。」

translations.literal: Therefore I listened to him.'
translations.idiomatic: So I followed his advice.'

sentences.zh: 良曰：「料大王士卒足以當項王乎？」

translations.literal: Liang said: 'In your estimation, are Your Majesty's soldiers sufficient to confront King Xiang?'
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang asked: 'Do you think your troops can stand against Xiang Yu?'

sentences.zh: 沛公默然，曰：「固不如也，且為之柰何？」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei was silent, said: 'Certainly not as good, and what can be done about it?'
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei fell silent: 'Of course not. What can we do?'

sentences.zh: 張良曰：「請往謂項伯，言沛公不敢背項王也。」

translations.literal: Zhang Liang said: 'Allow me to go speak to Xiang Bo, saying that the Duke of Pei dares not betray King Xiang.'
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang said: 'Let me go speak to Xiang Bo and assure him that the Duke of Pei would never betray Xiang Yu.'

sentences.zh: 沛公曰：「君安與項伯有故？」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei said: 'How does my lord have previous acquaintance with Xiang Bo?'
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei asked: 'How do you know Xiang Bo?'

sentences.zh: 張良曰：「秦時與臣游，項伯殺人，臣活之。

translations.literal: Zhang Liang said: 'In Qin times he associated with your servant, Xiang Bo killed a man, your servant saved him.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang explained: 'During the Qin dynasty, Xiang Bo and I were friends. He killed someone, and I saved his life.'

sentences.zh: 今事有急，故幸來告良。」

translations.literal: Now matters are urgent, therefore fortunately he came to inform Liang.'
translations.idiomatic: Now the situation is critical, so he came to warn me.'

sentences.zh: 沛公曰「孰與君少長？」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei said: 'Who is older or younger than my lord?'
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei asked: 'Who is older, you or Xiang Bo?'

sentences.zh: 良曰：「長於臣。」

translations.literal: Liang said: 'Older than your servant.'
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang replied: 'He is older than I.'

sentences.zh: 沛公曰「君為我呼入，吾得兄事之。」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei said: 'My lord call him in for me, I will be able to serve him as an elder brother.'
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei said: 'Please invite him in for me. I would be honored to treat him as an elder brother.'

sentences.zh: 張良出，要項伯。

translations.literal: Zhang Liang went out, intercepted Xiang Bo.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang went out and met Xiang Bo on the way.

sentences.zh: 項伯即入見沛公。

translations.literal: Xiang Bo immediately entered to see the Duke of Pei.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Bo immediately went in to meet the Duke of Pei.

sentences.zh: 沛公奉卮酒為壽，約為婚姻，曰：「吾入關，秋豪不敢有所近，籍吏民，封府庫，而待將軍。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei presented a goblet of wine as a toast, agreed to marriage alliance, said: 'When I entered the passes, I dared not approach even the finest hair, registered the officials and people, sealed the treasuries, and waited for the general.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei offered a toast with a goblet of wine and proposed a marriage alliance: 'When I entered the passes, I didn't touch even the smallest thing. I registered the officials and people, sealed the treasuries, and waited for you, General.'

sentences.zh: 所以遣將守關者，備他盜之出入與非常也。

translations.literal: The reason I sent generals to guard the pass was to prepare for other bandits' entry and exit and unusual circumstances.
translations.idiomatic: I stationed generals to guard the pass to prevent other bandits from entering or leaving and to guard against emergencies.'

sentences.zh: 日夜望將軍至，豈敢反乎！

translations.literal: Day and night I hoped for the general's arrival, how would I dare rebel!
translations.idiomatic: I've been waiting day and night for your arrival, General. How could I possibly rebel?'

sentences.zh: 願伯具言臣之不敢倍德也。」

translations.literal: I wish Bo to fully explain that your servant dares not betray virtue.'
translations.idiomatic: Please, Bo, explain fully that I would never betray such kindness.'

sentences.zh: 項伯許諾。

translations.literal: Xiang Bo agreed.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Bo agreed to help.

sentences.zh: 謂沛公曰：「旦日不可不蚤自來謝項王。」

translations.literal: He told the Duke of Pei: 'Tomorrow you must come early yourself to thank King Xiang.'
translations.idiomatic: He told the Duke of Pei: 'Tomorrow you must come early in person to express thanks to King Xiang.'

sentences.zh: 沛公曰：「諾。」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei said: 'Yes.'
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei agreed: 'Very well.'

sentences.zh: 於是項伯復夜去，至軍中，具以沛公言報項王。

translations.literal: Thereupon Xiang Bo again left at night, reached the army, fully reported the Duke of Pei's words to King Xiang.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Bo then departed again that night and returned to camp, where he fully reported the Duke of Pei's words to King Xiang.

sentences.zh: 因言曰：「沛公不先破關中，公豈敢入乎？

translations.literal: He then said: 'If the Duke of Pei had not first broken into Guanzhong, how would you, my lord, dare enter?
translations.idiomatic: He then added: 'If the Duke of Pei hadn't conquered Guanzhong first, would you have dared to enter?'

sentences.zh: 今人有大功而擊之，不義也，不如因善遇之。」

translations.literal: Now someone has great merit yet you attack him, this is unrighteous, it is better to take advantage of goodness and treat him well.'
translations.idiomatic: Now you're attacking someone who has performed great service. That's unjust. Better to reward him for his good deeds.'

sentences.zh: 項王許諾。

translations.literal: King Xiang agreed.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang agreed to this advice.

translations.literal: Xiang Bo, Chu's left minister, was Xiang Yu's youngest uncle. He had long been good friends with Marquis Liu Zhang Liang. Zhang Liang was at this time following Liu Bang. Xiang Bo then galloped at night to Liu Bang's army. He privately saw Zhang Liang and fully told him the matters, wishing to call Zhang Liang to go with him. He said: 'Do not follow him and die together.' Zhang Liang said: 'I escorted Liu Bang for the King of Han. Liu Bang's matters are now urgent. To flee would not be righteous. I cannot fail to tell him.' Liang then entered and fully told Liu Bang. Liu Bang was greatly startled and said: 'What should I do?' Zhang Liang said: 'Who devised this plan for the great king?' He said: 'A small man advised me, saying "Bar the pass, do not admit the feudal lords. You can rule all Qin lands." So I listened to him.' Liang said: 'Do you estimate that the great king's soldiers are sufficient to match King Xiang?' Liu Bang was silent, then said: 'Certainly not equal. Moreover, what should I do?' Zhang Liang said: 'Please go tell Xiang Bo that Liu Bang dares not turn against King Xiang.' Liu Bang said: 'Sir, how do you have an old friendship with Xiang Bo?' Zhang Liang said: 'During Qin times, Xiang Bo wandered with me. Xiang Bo killed a man, and I saved him. Now matters are urgent, so fortunately he came to tell me.' Liu Bang said: 'Who is younger or older than you?' Liang said: 'Older than me.' Liu Bang said: 'Sir, call him in for me. I will treat him as an elder brother.' Zhang Liang went out and intercepted Xiang Bo. Xiang Bo immediately entered and saw Liu Bang. Liu Bang offered a goblet of wine as a toast and agreed to marriage, saying: 'When I entered the passes, I dared not approach even the smallest thing. I registered the officials and people, sealed the treasuries, and waited for the general. The reason I sent a general to guard the pass was to prepare for other bandits entering and exiting, and for extraordinary circumstances. Day and night I hoped for the general to arrive. How would I dare rebel! I hope you will fully explain that I, your minister, do not dare to betray virtue.' Xiang Bo agreed. He said to Liu Bang: 'Tomorrow you must come early to apologize to King Xiang.' Liu Bang said: 'Yes.' Therefore Xiang Bo again left at night and arrived in the army camp. He fully reported Liu Bang's words to King Xiang. He then said: 'If Liu Bang had not first broken Guanzhong, how would you have dared to enter? Now someone has achieved great merit, yet you would strike him. That is not righteous. It is better to take advantage of this and treat him well.' King Xiang agreed.

sentences.zh: 沛公旦日從百餘騎來見項王，至鴻門，謝曰：「臣與將軍戮力而攻秦，將軍戰河北，臣戰河南，然不自意能先入關破秦，得復見將軍於此。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei on the next day came with more than a hundred horsemen to see King Xiang, reached Hongmen, apologized saying: 'Your servant and the general united efforts to attack Qin, the general fought north of the Yellow River, your servant fought south of the Yellow River, yet I did not expect to be able to enter the passes first and destroy Qin, to be able to see the general again here.
translations.idiomatic: The next day the Duke of Pei came with over a hundred horsemen to meet King Xiang. They arrived at Hongmen, where he apologized: 'Your servant and you, General, united our efforts to attack Qin. You fought north of the Yellow River while I fought south. I never expected to enter the passes first and conquer Qin, allowing me to meet you again here.'

sentences.zh: 今者有小人之言，令將軍與臣有郤。」

translations.literal: Now there are the words of petty men, causing the general and your servant to have a rift.'
translations.idiomatic: Now some petty individuals have spoken ill, creating discord between you, General, and me.'

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「此沛公左司馬曹無傷言之；

translations.literal: King Xiang said: 'This was spoken by the Duke of Pei's left commander Cao Wushang;
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang said: 'This was said by the Duke of Pei's left commander Cao Wushang.'

sentences.zh: 不然，籍何以至此。」

translations.literal: If not, how would Ji have come to this?'
translations.idiomatic: If not for that, how would I be here?'

sentences.zh: 項王即日因留沛公與飲。

translations.literal: King Xiang that very day therefore detained the Duke of Pei to drink together.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang therefore detained the Duke of Pei that very day for a drinking banquet.

sentences.zh: 項王、項伯東向坐。

translations.literal: King Xiang and Xiang Bo sat facing east.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang and Xiang Bo took seats facing east.

sentences.zh: 亞父南向坐。

translations.literal: The Secondary Father sat facing south.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Zeng, the Secondary Father, sat facing south.

sentences.zh: 亞父者，范增也。

translations.literal: The Secondary Father was Fan Zeng.
translations.idiomatic: The Secondary Father was none other than Fan Zeng.

sentences.zh: 沛公北向坐，張良西向侍。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei sat facing north, Zhang Liang served facing west.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei took a seat facing north, with Zhang Liang attending him while facing west.

sentences.zh: 范增數目項王，舉所佩玉珪以示之者三，項王默然不應。

translations.literal: Fan Zeng repeatedly glared at King Xiang, raised the jade tablet he wore at his belt to show it to him three times, King Xiang remained silent and did not respond.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Zeng repeatedly signaled King Xiang with his eyes and raised the jade tablet from his belt to show him three times, but King Xiang remained silent and gave no response.

sentences.zh: 范增起，出召項莊，謂曰：「君王為人不忍，若入前為壽，壽畢，請以劍舞，因擊沛公於坐，殺之。

translations.literal: Fan Zeng rose, went out and summoned Xiang Zhuang, said to him: 'Our king is soft-hearted by nature, so enter and offer a toast before him, after the toast is finished, request to perform sword dance, then strike the Duke of Pei at his seat and kill him.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Zeng rose and went out to summon Xiang Zhuang: 'Our king is too merciful by nature. Go in and offer him a toast. When the toast is done, ask to perform a sword dance, then strike the Duke of Pei where he sits and kill him.'

sentences.zh: 不者，若屬皆且為所虜。」

translations.literal: If not, all of you will certainly be captured by him.'
translations.idiomatic: If you don't, all of you will surely end up as his captives.'

sentences.zh: 莊則入為壽，壽畢，曰：「君王與沛公飲，軍中無以為樂，請以劍舞。」

translations.literal: Zhuang then entered to offer a toast, after the toast was finished, said: 'The king and Duke of Pei are drinking, the army has nothing for entertainment, allow me to perform sword dance.'
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Zhuang entered and offered a toast. When it was done, he said: 'Our king and the Duke of Pei are drinking. The army has no entertainment. Allow me to perform a sword dance.'

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「諾。」

translations.literal: King Xiang said: 'Yes.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang agreed: 'Very well.'

sentences.zh: 項莊拔劍起舞，項伯亦拔劍起舞，常以身翼蔽沛公，莊不得擊。

translations.literal: Xiang Zhuang drew his sword and began to dance, Xiang Bo also drew his sword and danced, constantly using his body as wings to shield the Duke of Pei, Zhuang could not strike.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Zhuang drew his sword and began dancing. Xiang Bo also drew his sword and danced, constantly shielding the Duke of Pei with his body. Zhuang could not strike.

sentences.zh: 於是張良至軍門，見樊噲。

translations.literal: Thereupon Zhang Liang reached the army gate, saw Fan Kuai.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang then went to the army gate and met Fan Kuai.

sentences.zh: 樊噲曰：「今日之事何如？」

translations.literal: Fan Kuai said: 'How are matters today?'
translations.idiomatic: Fan Kuai asked: 'What's happening today?'

sentences.zh: 良曰：「甚急。

translations.literal: Liang said: 'Very urgent.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang said: 'Extremely urgent.'

sentences.zh: 今者項莊拔劍舞，其意常在沛公也。」

translations.literal: Now Xiang Zhuang has drawn his sword to dance, his intent is constantly on the Duke of Pei.'
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Zhuang has drawn his sword to dance, and his intentions are clearly fixed on the Duke of Pei.'

sentences.zh: 噲曰：「此迫矣，臣請入，與之同命。」

translations.literal: Kuai said: 'This is urgent, your servant requests to enter and share the same fate.'
translations.idiomatic: Fan Kuai said: 'This is critical. I request permission to enter and face the same danger.'

sentences.zh: 噲即帶劍擁盾入軍門。

translations.literal: Kuai immediately belted on his sword and held his shield, entering the army gate.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Kuai immediately strapped on his sword and grasped his shield, then entered the army gate.

sentences.zh: 交戟之衛士欲止不內，樊噲側其盾以撞，衛士仆地，噲遂入，披帷西向立，瞋目視項王，頭髪上指，目眥盡裂。

translations.literal: The crossed-halberd guards wished to stop him but would not admit him, Fan Kuai tilted his shield to strike them, the guards fell to the ground, Kuai then entered, parted the curtain and stood facing west, glared at King Xiang with angry eyes, his hair stood on end, the corners of his eyes were completely split.
translations.idiomatic: The guards with crossed halberds tried to stop him from entering. Fan Kuai tilted his shield and knocked them down. He then entered, parted the curtains, and stood facing west. He glared furiously at King Xiang, his hair standing on end and the corners of his eyes splitting open.

sentences.zh: 項王按劍而跽曰：「客何為者？」

translations.literal: King Xiang pressed his sword and knelt saying: 'What does the guest do?'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang gripped his sword and knelt up: 'Who is this guest?'

sentences.zh: 張良曰：「沛公之參乘樊噲者也。」

translations.literal: Zhang Liang said: 'He is the Duke of Pei's chariot companion Fan Kuai.'
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang said: 'This is Fan Kuai, the Duke of Pei's chariot companion.'

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「壯士，賜之卮酒。」

translations.literal: King Xiang said: 'Brave warrior, grant him a goblet of wine.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang said: 'Brave warrior! Give him a goblet of wine.'

sentences.zh: 則與斗卮酒。

translations.literal: Then gave him a dou goblet of wine.
translations.idiomatic: They gave him a large goblet of wine.

sentences.zh: 噲拜謝，起，立而飲之。

translations.literal: Kuai bowed in thanks, rose, stood and drank it.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Kuai bowed in thanks, stood up, and drank it down standing.

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「賜之彘肩。」

translations.literal: King Xiang said: 'Grant him a pig's shoulder.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang said: 'Give him a pig's shoulder.'

sentences.zh: 則與一生彘肩。

translations.literal: Then gave him one raw pig shoulder.
translations.idiomatic: They gave him a whole raw pig's shoulder.

sentences.zh: 樊噲覆其盾於地，加彘肩上，拔劍切而啗之。

translations.literal: Fan Kuai overturned his shield on the ground, placed the pig shoulder on it, drew his sword and carved and ate it.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Kuai flipped his shield upside down on the ground, placed the pig's shoulder on it, drew his sword, and began carving and eating it.

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「壯士，能復飲乎？」

translations.literal: King Xiang said: 'Brave warrior, can you drink again?'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang said: 'Brave warrior! Can you drink more?'

sentences.zh: 樊噲曰：「臣死且不避，卮酒安足辭！

translations.literal: Fan Kuai said: 'Your servant does not even avoid death, why should I decline a goblet of wine!
translations.idiomatic: Fan Kuai said: 'I wouldn't even shrink from death. Why would I refuse a goblet of wine?'

sentences.zh: 夫秦王有虎狼之心，殺人如不能舉，刑人如恐不勝，天下皆叛之。

translations.literal: As for the Qin king having the heart of a tiger and wolf, killing people as if unable to lift them, punishing people as if fearing not to prevail, all under heaven have rebelled against him.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin king has the heart of a tiger or wolf. He kills people as if he can't get enough, punishes them as if he fears he won't finish the job. The whole world has turned against him.

sentences.zh: 懷王與諸將約曰『先破秦入咸陽者王之』。

translations.literal: King Huai made an agreement with the generals saying 'Whoever first breaks Qin and enters Xianyang will be made king of it.'
translations.idiomatic: King Huai agreed with all the generals: 'Whoever first conquers Qin and enters Xianyang will be made king there.'

sentences.zh: 今沛公先破秦入咸陽，豪毛不敢有所近，封閉宮室，還軍霸上，以待大王來。

translations.literal: Now the Duke of Pei first broke Qin and entered Xianyang, he dared not approach even the finest hair, sealed the palaces, returned his army to Bashang, to wait for Your Majesty to come.
translations.idiomatic: Now the Duke of Pei was the first to conquer Qin and enter Xianyang. He didn't touch even the smallest thing. He sealed the palaces and withdrew his army to Bashang to await Your Majesty's arrival.

sentences.zh: 故遣將守關者，備他盜出入與非常也。

translations.literal: Therefore I sent generals to guard the pass to prepare for other bandits entering and exiting and unusual circumstances.
translations.idiomatic: That's why I stationed generals to guard the pass—to prevent other bandits from coming and going and to guard against emergencies.

sentences.zh: 勞苦而功高如此，未有封侯之賞，而聽細說，欲誅有功之人。

translations.literal: To labor and achieve merit so great, yet not have the reward of being enfeoffed as marquess, but listen to petty words and desire to execute the meritorious person.
translations.idiomatic: After such toil and such great achievement, he hasn't even received the reward of being made a marquess. Yet you listen to petty gossip and want to execute a man of great merit.

sentences.zh: 此亡秦之續耳，竊為大王不取也。」

translations.literal: This is merely the continuation of fallen Qin, I privately consider it not worthwhile for Your Majesty.'
translations.idiomatic: This is just continuing the ways of doomed Qin. I privately think it's not worth Your Majesty's while.'

sentences.zh: 項王未有以應，曰：「坐。」

translations.literal: King Xiang had nothing with which to respond, said: 'Sit.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang had no response. He said: 'Sit down.'

sentences.zh: 樊噲從良坐。

translations.literal: Fan Kuai followed Liang and sat.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Kuai sat down next to Zhang Liang.

sentences.zh: 坐須臾，沛公起如廁，因招樊噲出。

translations.literal: Sat for a short while, the Duke of Pei rose as if to relieve himself, and thereby summoned Fan Kuai out.
translations.idiomatic: After sitting for a short time, the Duke of Pei rose as if to use the toilet and signaled Fan Kuai to follow him out.

translations.literal: The next day Liu Bang came to see King Xiang with more than a hundred riders. He arrived at Hongmen and apologized, saying: 'Your minister united with the general to attack Qin. The general fought north of the river, your minister fought south of the river. Yet I did not expect to be able to enter the passes first and break Qin, and thus meet the general again here. Now there are the words of petty men, causing a rift between the general and your minister.' King Xiang said: 'This was spoken by Liu Bang's left adjutant Cao Wushang; Otherwise, why would I, Ji, have come to this point.' King Xiang therefore kept Liu Bang that day and drank with him. King Xiang and Xiang Bo sat facing east. Yafu sat facing south. Yafu was Fan Zeng. Liu Bang sat facing north. Zhang Liang served facing west. Fan Zeng frequently glanced at King Xiang. He raised his jade tablet three times to signal him. King Xiang remained silent and did not respond. Fan Zeng rose and went out to summon Xiang Zhuang. He said: 'Our lord king is not a cruel person. If you enter and make a toast first, and when the toast is finished, request to dance with swords, then take advantage to strike Liu Bang at his seat and kill him. If not, you and all your kind will moreover be captured by him.' Zhuang then entered and made a toast. When the toast was finished, he said: 'The lord king is drinking with Liu Bang. The army has nothing for merriment. Please allow me to dance with swords.' King Xiang said: 'Yes.' Xiang Zhuang drew his sword and began to dance. Xiang Bo also drew his sword and danced. He constantly used his body to flank and shield Liu Bang. Zhuang could not strike. Therefore Zhang Liang went to the army gate and saw Fan Kuai. Fan Kuai said: 'How are matters today?' Liang said: 'Very urgent. Now Xiang Zhuang draws his sword and dances. His intent is constantly on Liu Bang.' Kuai said: 'This is critical. Your minister requests to enter and share the same fate with him.' Kuai immediately strapped on his sword, embraced his shield, and entered the army gate. The guards with crossed halberds wished to stop him and not admit him. Fan Kuai tilted his shield to collide with them. The guards fell to the ground. Kuai then entered, parted the curtain, stood facing west, glared at King Xiang with his eyes. His hair stood on end, his eyes were completely bloodshot. King Xiang pressed his sword and knelt, saying: 'What is this guest doing?' Zhang Liang said: 'He is Liu Bang's chariot driver, Fan Kuai.' King Xiang said: 'Brave warrior. Grant him a goblet of wine.' They then gave him a large goblet of wine. Kuai bowed in thanks, rose, stood and drank it. King Xiang said: 'Grant him a pork shoulder.' They then gave him a whole pork shoulder. Fan Kuai overturned his shield on the ground, placed the pork shoulder on it, drew his sword, cut it, and ate it. King Xiang said: 'Brave warrior, can you drink more?' Fan Kuai said: 'Your minister would not avoid even death. How could I refuse a goblet of wine! The Qin king has the heart of a tiger or wolf. He kills people as if unable to lift them all, punishes people as if fearing not enough. The world has all rebelled against him. King Huai agreed with the generals that 'Whoever first breaks Qin and enters Xianyang will rule it.' Now Liu Bang first broke Qin and entered Xianyang. He dared not approach even the smallest thing. He sealed the palaces, returned his army to Bashang, and waited for the great king to come. Therefore he sent a general to guard the pass, to prepare for other bandits entering and exiting, and for extraordinary circumstances. To have toiled and achieved such high merit, yet not received the reward of enfeoffment as marquis, and instead listen to petty slander, desiring to execute meritorious people. This is just continuing the ways of perished Qin. I secretly advise the great king not to do this.' King Xiang had nothing to respond with and said: 'Sit.' Fan Kuai sat next to Liang. After sitting a brief moment, Liu Bang rose as if going to the toilet, and took advantage to beckon Fan Kuai out.

sentences.zh: 沛公已出，項王使都尉陳平召沛公。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei had already gone out, King Xiang sent Commandant Chen Ping to summon the Duke of Pei.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei had already left. King Xiang sent his commandant Chen Ping to call him back.

sentences.zh: 沛公曰：「今者出，未辭也，為之柰何？」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei said: 'Just now I went out without taking leave, what can be done about it?'
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei said: 'I just left without properly excusing myself. What should I do?'

sentences.zh: 樊噲曰：「大行不顧細謹，大禮不辭小讓。

translations.literal: Fan Kuai said: 'Great undertakings do not concern themselves with petty cautions, great rites do not decline small refusals.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Kuai said: 'When undertaking great deeds, don't worry about minor etiquette. When performing important rituals, don't refuse small courtesies.'

sentences.zh: 如今人方為刀俎，我為魚肉，何辭為。」

translations.literal: Now others are the knife and cutting board, we are the fish and meat, why make excuses?'
translations.idiomatic: Now others hold the knife and cutting board, while we are the fish and meat. Why bother with excuses?'

sentences.zh: 於是遂去。

translations.literal: Thereupon they departed.
translations.idiomatic: And so they left.

sentences.zh: 乃令張良留謝。

translations.literal: They then ordered Zhang Liang to remain and apologize.
translations.idiomatic: They instructed Zhang Liang to stay behind and offer their apologies.

sentences.zh: 良問曰：「大王來何操？」

translations.literal: Liang asked: 'What does Your Majesty bring?'
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang asked: 'What gifts has Your Majesty brought?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「我持白璧一雙，欲獻項王，玉斗一雙，欲與亞父，會其怒，不敢獻。

translations.literal: Said: 'I brought a pair of white jade discs, wishing to present them to King Xiang, a pair of jade goblets, wishing to give them to the Secondary Father, but encountering his anger, I dared not present them.
translations.idiomatic: He replied: 'I brought a pair of white jade discs to present to King Xiang and a pair of jade goblets for the Secondary Father. But encountering his anger, I dared not present them.'

sentences.zh: 公為我獻之」張良曰：「謹諾。」

translations.literal: My lord present them for me.' Zhang Liang said: 'Respectfully yes.'
translations.idiomatic: Please present them on my behalf.' Zhang Liang replied: 'I will do so respectfully.'

sentences.zh: 當是時，項王軍在鴻門下，沛公軍在霸上，相去四十里。

translations.literal: At this time, King Xiang's army was below Hongmen, the Duke of Pei's army at Bashang, separated by forty li.
translations.idiomatic: At this juncture, King Xiang's army was stationed below Hongmen, while the Duke of Pei's army was at Bashang, forty li apart.

sentences.zh: 沛公則置車騎，脫身獨騎，與樊噲、夏侯嬰、靳彊、紀信等四人持劍盾步走，從酈山下，道芷陽閒行。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei then abandoned his chariots and cavalry, escaped alone on horseback, with Fan Kuai, Xiahou Ying, Jin Qiang, Ji Xin and four others holding swords and shields walking on foot, from below Li Mountain, taking the path through Zhiyang.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei abandoned his chariots and cavalry, slipped away alone on horseback with Fan Kuai, Xiahou Ying, Jin Qiang, Ji Xin, and four others. They walked on foot carrying swords and shields, taking a path below Mount Li through Zhiyang.

sentences.zh: 沛公謂張良曰：「從此道至吾軍，不過二十里耳。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei told Zhang Liang: 'From this road to my army, it is no more than twenty li.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei told Zhang Liang: 'This road to my army is only about twenty li.'

sentences.zh: 度我至軍中，公乃入。」

translations.literal: Estimate when I reach the army camp, my lord then enter.'
translations.idiomatic: Once you calculate I've reached camp, then you may enter.'

sentences.zh: 沛公已去，閒至軍中，張良入謝，曰：「沛公不勝桮杓，不能辭。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei had departed, after a while reached the army camp, Zhang Liang entered to apologize, said: 'The Duke of Pei cannot handle the wine cups, could not take leave.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei had left. After a while Zhang Liang reached the army camp and entered to offer apologies: 'The Duke of Pei couldn't handle all the toasts and had to leave without proper farewells.'

sentences.zh: 謹使臣良奉白璧一雙，再拜獻大王足下；

translations.literal: Respectfully sending your servant Liang to present a pair of white jade discs, bowing twice to offer them to Your Majesty's feet;
translations.idiomatic: I respectfully send my servant Zhang Liang to present a pair of white jade discs, bowing twice to offer them at Your Majesty's feet.

sentences.zh: 玉斗一雙，再拜奉大將軍足下。」

translations.literal: A pair of jade goblets, bowing twice to present them to the Supreme General's feet.'
translations.idiomatic: And a pair of jade goblets, bowing twice to present them at the Supreme General's feet.'

sentences.zh: 項王曰：「沛公安在？」

translations.literal: King Xiang said: 'Where is the Duke of Pei?'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang asked: 'Where is the Duke of Pei?'

sentences.zh: 良曰：「聞大王有意督過之，脫身獨去，已至軍矣。」

translations.literal: Liang said: 'Heard that Your Majesty intended to blame him for his faults, he escaped alone and departed, has already reached his army.'
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang said: 'He heard that Your Majesty intended to hold him accountable for his faults, so he slipped away alone and has already reached his army.'

sentences.zh: 項王則受璧，置之坐上。

translations.literal: King Xiang then accepted the jade discs, placed them on his seat.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang accepted the jade discs and placed them on his seat.

sentences.zh: 亞父受玉斗，置之地，拔劍撞而破之，曰：「唉！

translations.literal: The Secondary Father accepted the jade goblets, placed them on the ground, drew his sword and smashed them, said: 'Alas!
translations.idiomatic: The Secondary Father accepted the jade goblets, threw them on the ground, drew his sword and smashed them, exclaiming: 'Alas!'

sentences.zh: 豎子不足與謀。

translations.literal: That brat is not worth consulting with.
translations.idiomatic: That young upstart isn't worth consulting.

sentences.zh: 奪項王天下者，必沛公也，吾屬今為之虜矣。」

translations.literal: The one who will seize King Xiang's world will certainly be the Duke of Pei, we will now become captives for him.'
translations.idiomatic: The one who will take the world from King Xiang will surely be the Duke of Pei. We will all end up as his prisoners.'

sentences.zh: 沛公至軍，立誅殺曹無傷。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei reached the army, immediately executed Cao Wushang.
translations.idiomatic: Upon reaching his army, the Duke of Pei immediately had Cao Wushang executed.

translations.literal: Liu Bang had already left. King Xiang sent Commandery Captain Chen Ping to summon Liu Bang back. Liu Bang said: 'I left just now without taking leave. What should I do?' Fan Kuai said: 'Great undertakings do not consider petty cautions. Great rites do not refuse small concessions. Now people are just the knife and chopping block, we are the fish and meat. What ceremony is there for?' Therefore he left. He then ordered Zhang Liang to stay and apologize. Liang asked: 'What did the great king bring?' He said: 'I brought a pair of white jade discs, intending to offer them to King Xiang, and a pair of jade goblets, intending to give them to Yafu. But encountering his anger, I did not dare offer them. You offer them for me.' Zhang Liang said: 'Respectfully, yes.' At this time, King Xiang's army was below Hongmen. Liu Bang's army was at Bashang. They were forty li apart. Liu Bang then abandoned his chariot and cavalry. He escaped alone on horseback with Fan Kuai, Xiahou Ying, Jin Qiang, and Ji Xin—these four men carrying swords and shields—walking on foot. They went from below Mount Li, taking the road through Zhiyang. Liu Bang said to Zhang Liang: 'From this road to my army, it's not over twenty li. Estimate when I arrive in the army camp, then you enter.' Liu Bang had already left. After a while he arrived in the army camp. Zhang Liang entered and apologized, saying: 'Liu Bang was overcome by the wine and could not take leave. Respectfully, your minister Liang presents a pair of white jade discs. I twice bow and offer them to the great king's feet; A pair of jade goblets. I twice bow and present them to the great general's feet.' King Xiang said: 'Where is Liu Bang?' Liang said: 'He heard the great king intended to blame him. He escaped alone and left. He has already arrived at his army.' King Xiang then received the jade disc and placed it on his seat. Yafu received the jade goblet, placed it on the ground, drew his sword, struck it, and broke it, saying: 'Alas! This youngster is not worth planning with. The one who will seize King Xiang's world will certainly be Liu Bang. We will now become his captives.' Liu Bang arrived at his army and immediately executed Cao Wushang.

sentences.zh: 居數日，項羽引兵西屠咸陽，殺秦降王子嬰，燒秦宮室，火三月不滅；

translations.literal: After several days, Xiang Yu led his troops west to slaughter Xianyang, killed the surrendered Qin prince Zi Ying, burned the Qin palaces, the fire did not extinguish for three months;
translations.idiomatic: A few days later, Xiang Yu led his army west and massacred the population of Xianyang. He executed the surrendered Qin prince Zi Ying and set fire to the Qin palaces. The flames burned for three months without going out.

sentences.zh: 收其貨寶婦女而東。

translations.literal: Collected their goods, treasures, and women and went east.
translations.idiomatic: He gathered up all the riches, treasures, and women, then marched east.

sentences.zh: 人或說項王曰：「關中阻山河四塞，地肥饒，可都以霸。」

translations.literal: Someone advised King Xiang saying: 'Guanzhong is blocked by mountains and rivers on four sides, the land is fertile and rich, it can be made the capital to dominate.'
translations.idiomatic: Someone advised King Xiang: 'Guanzhong is protected on four sides by mountains and rivers. The land is fertile and rich. It would make an excellent capital from which to rule.'

sentences.zh: 項王見秦宮皆以燒殘破，又心懷思欲東歸，曰：「富貴不歸故鄉，如衣繡夜行，誰知之者！」

translations.literal: King Xiang saw that the Qin palaces were all burned and ruined, moreover his heart longed for home and wished to return east, said: 'To be wealthy and noble but not return to one's hometown is like wearing embroidered clothes at night—who would know!'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang saw that the Qin palaces were all burned and in ruins. He longed for home and wished to return east, saying: 'To achieve wealth and nobility but not return to your hometown is like wearing fine embroidered clothes in the dark—who would know!'

sentences.zh: 說者曰：「人言楚人沐猴而冠耳，果然。」

translations.literal: The advisor said: 'People say Chu people are macaques wearing hats, indeed.'
translations.idiomatic: The advisor said: 'People say Chu people are just monkeys in caps. It's true.'

sentences.zh: 項王聞之，烹說者。

translations.literal: King Xiang heard this, boiled the advisor.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang heard this and had the advisor boiled alive.

translations.literal: After several days, Xiang Yu led his troops west and slaughtered Xianyang. He killed the Qin surrendered prince Zi Ying, burned the Qin palaces. The fire did not extinguish for three months; He collected their goods, treasures, and women and went east. Someone advised King Xiang, saying: 'Guanzhong is blocked by mountains and rivers on four sides. The land is fertile and rich. You can make it your capital and dominate.' King Xiang saw that all the Qin palaces were burned and ruined. Moreover, his heart longed to return east. He said: 'Wealth and nobility without returning to your hometown is like wearing embroidered clothes while walking at night—who would know!' The adviser said: 'People say Chu people are bathing monkeys wearing hats. Indeed.' King Xiang heard it and boiled the adviser.

sentences.zh: 項王使人致命懷王。

translations.literal: King Xiang sent someone to report the command to King Huai.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang sent a messenger to report to King Huai.

sentences.zh: 懷王曰：「如約。」

translations.literal: King Huai said: 'As agreed.'
translations.idiomatic: King Huai replied: 'As we agreed.'

sentences.zh: 乃尊懷王為義帝。

translations.literal: They then honored King Huai as the Righteous Emperor.
translations.idiomatic: They then honored King Huai with the title Righteous Emperor.

sentences.zh: 項王欲自王，先王諸將相。

translations.literal: King Xiang wished to become king himself, first enfeoffed the various generals and chancellors.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang wanted to become king himself, so he first enfeoffed the various generals and chancellors as kings.

sentences.zh: 謂曰：「天下初發難時，假立諸侯後以伐秦。

translations.literal: He said to them: 'When the world first rose in rebellion, we temporarily established descendants of the feudal lords to attack Qin.
translations.idiomatic: He told them: 'When the world first rebelled, we temporarily installed descendants of the old feudal lords to attack Qin.'

sentences.zh: 然身被堅執銳首事，暴露於野三年，滅秦定天下者，皆將相諸君與籍之力也。

translations.literal: Yet those who personally wore armor and wielded sharp weapons taking the lead, exposed in the wilds for three years, who destroyed Qin and pacified the world, were all due to the efforts of you generals and chancellors and Ji.
translations.idiomatic: Yet those who personally donned armor and wielded weapons to lead the charge, exposed to the elements in the wilderness for three years, who destroyed Qin and brought peace to the world—all this was due to the efforts of you generals, chancellors, and myself.

sentences.zh: 義帝雖無功，故當分其地而王之。」

translations.literal: Although the Righteous Emperor had no merit, therefore we should divide territory and make him king.'
translations.idiomatic: Although the Righteous Emperor contributed nothing, we should still divide territory and make him king out of respect.'

sentences.zh: 諸將皆曰：「善。」

translations.literal: All the generals said: 'Good.'
translations.idiomatic: All the generals replied: 'Excellent.'

sentences.zh: 乃分天下，立諸將為侯王。

translations.literal: They then divided the world, established the various generals as marquesses and kings.
translations.idiomatic: They then divided up the empire, enfeoffing the various generals as marquesses and kings.

sentences.zh: 項王、范增疑沛公之有天下，業已講解，又惡負約，恐諸侯叛之，乃陰謀曰：「巴、蜀道險，秦之遷人皆居蜀。」

translations.literal: King Xiang and Fan Zeng suspected that the Duke of Pei would possess the world, the matter was already settled, moreover they disliked breaking agreements, feared the feudal lords would rebel against them, so secretly plotted saying: 'The roads to Ba and Shu are dangerous, Qin's banished people all live in Shu.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang and Fan Zeng suspected that the Duke of Pei would eventually rule the world. The matter was already settled, and they disliked breaking agreements for fear the feudal lords would rebel. So they secretly plotted: 'The roads to Ba and Shu are treacherous, and all of Qin's banished criminals live in Shu.'

sentences.zh: 乃曰：「巴、蜀亦關中地也。」

translations.literal: They then said: 'Ba and Shu are also Guanzhong territory.'
translations.idiomatic: They reasoned: 'Ba and Shu are also part of Guanzhong.'

sentences.zh: 故立沛公為漢王，王巴、蜀、漢中，都南鄭。

translations.literal: Therefore established the Duke of Pei as King of Han, ruling Ba, Shu, and Hanzhong, with capital at Nanzheng.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore they installed the Duke of Pei as King of Han, giving him control of Ba, Shu, and Hanzhong, with his capital at Nanzheng.

sentences.zh: 而三分關中，王秦降將以距塞漢王。

translations.literal: And divided Guanzhong into three parts, made the surrendered Qin generals kings to block and contain the Han king.
translations.idiomatic: They divided Guanzhong into three parts and installed the surrendered Qin generals as kings to block and contain the King of Han.

sentences.zh: 項王乃立章邯為雍王，王咸陽以西，都廢丘。

translations.literal: King Xiang then established Zhang Han as King of Yong, ruling west of Xianyang, with capital at Fei Qiu.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then installed Zhang Han as King of Yong, giving him control west of Xianyang, with his capital at Feiqiu.

sentences.zh: 長史欣者，故為櫟陽獄掾，嘗有德於項梁；

translations.literal: Chief Clerk Xin was formerly the Queyang prison official, had once shown kindness to Xiang Liang;
translations.idiomatic: Chief Clerk Xin had formerly been the prison official in Queyang and had once shown kindness to Xiang Liang.

sentences.zh: 都尉董翳者，本勸章邯降楚。

translations.literal: Commandant Dong Yi was originally the one who advised Zhang Han to surrender to Chu.
translations.idiomatic: Commandant Dong Yi had originally been the one who persuaded Zhang Han to surrender to Chu.

sentences.zh: 故立司馬欣為塞王，王咸陽以東至河，都櫟陽；

translations.literal: Therefore established Sima Xin as King of Sai, ruling east of Xianyang to the Yellow River, with capital at Queyang;
translations.idiomatic: Therefore they installed Sima Xin as King of Sai, giving him control east of Xianyang up to the Yellow River, with his capital at Queyang.

sentences.zh: 立董翳為翟王，王上郡，都高奴。

translations.literal: Established Dong Yi as King of Di, ruling Shang commandery, with capital at Gao Nu.
translations.idiomatic: They installed Dong Yi as King of Di, giving him control of Shang commandery, with his capital at Gaonu.

sentences.zh: 徙魏王豹為西魏王，王河東，都平陽。

translations.literal: Moved King Bao of Wei to become King of Western Wei, ruling Hedong, with capital at Pingyang.
translations.idiomatic: They relocated King Bao of Wei to become King of Western Wei, giving him control of Hedong, with his capital at Pingyang.

sentences.zh: 瑕丘申陽者，張耳嬖臣也，先下河南（郡），迎楚河上，故立申陽為河南王，都雒陽。

translations.literal: Xiaqiu Shen Yang was Zhang Er's favored minister, first conquered Henan commandery, welcomed Chu along the Yellow River, therefore established Shen Yang as King of Henan, with capital at Luoyang.
translations.idiomatic: Shen Yang from Xiaqiu was Zhang Er's favorite minister. He had first conquered Henan commandery and welcomed Chu forces along the Yellow River. Therefore they installed Shen Yang as King of Henan, with his capital at Luoyang.

sentences.zh: 韓王成因故都，都陽翟。

translations.literal: King Cheng of Han remained at his original capital, capital Yangdi.
translations.idiomatic: King Cheng of Han kept his original capital at Yangdi.

sentences.zh: 趙將司馬卬定河內，數有功，故立卬為殷王，王河內，都朝歌。

translations.literal: Zhao general Sima Ang pacified Henan, repeatedly achieved merit, therefore established Ang as King of Yin, ruling Henan, with capital at Zhaoge.
translations.idiomatic: Zhao general Sima Ang pacified Henan and achieved repeated successes. Therefore they installed him as King of Yin, giving him control of Henan, with his capital at Zhaoge.

sentences.zh: 徙趙王歇為代王。

translations.literal: Moved King Xie of Zhao to become King of Dai.
translations.idiomatic: They relocated King Xie of Zhao to become King of Dai.

sentences.zh: 趙相張耳素賢，又從入關，故立耳為常山王，王趙地，都襄國。

translations.literal: Zhao chancellor Zhang Er was long known for his worthiness, moreover followed into the passes, therefore established Er as King of Changshan, ruling Zhao territory, with capital at Xiangguo.
translations.idiomatic: Zhao chancellor Zhang Er had long been recognized for his worthiness and had followed them into the passes. Therefore they installed him as King of Changshan, giving him control of Zhao territory, with his capital at Xiangguo.

sentences.zh: 當陽君黥布為楚將，常冠軍，故立布為九江王，都六。

translations.literal: Lord Dangyang Ying Bu served as Chu general, constantly led the vanguard, therefore established Bu as King of Jiujiang, with capital at Liu.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Dangyang Ying Bu had served as a Chu general and constantly led the vanguard. Therefore they installed him as King of Jiujiang, with his capital at Liu.

sentences.zh: 鄱君吳芮率百越佐諸侯，又從入關，故立芮為衡山王，都邾。

translations.literal: Lord of Po Wu Rui led the hundred Yue to assist the feudal lords, moreover followed into the passes, therefore established Rui as King of Hengshan, with capital at Zhu.
translations.idiomatic: Lord of Po Wu Rui had led the hundred Yue tribes to assist the feudal lords and had followed them into the passes. Therefore they installed him as King of Hengshan, with his capital at Zhu.

sentences.zh: 義帝柱國共敖將兵擊南郡，功多，因立敖為臨江王，都江陵。

translations.literal: The Righteous Emperor's Pillar of State Gong Ao led troops to attack Nanguo, achieved much merit, therefore established Ao as King of Linjiang, with capital at Jiangling.
translations.idiomatic: The Righteous Emperor's Pillar of State Gong Ao led troops to attack Nanguo and achieved great success. Therefore they installed him as King of Linjiang, with his capital at Jiangling.

sentences.zh: 徙燕王韓廣為遼東王。

translations.literal: Moved King Guang of Yan to become King of Liaodong.
translations.idiomatic: They relocated King Guang of Yan to become King of Liaodong.

sentences.zh: 燕將臧荼從楚救趙，因從入關，故立荼為燕王，都薊。

translations.literal: Yan general Zang Chu followed Chu to rescue Zhao, moreover followed into the passes, therefore established Chu as King of Yan, with capital at Ji.
translations.idiomatic: Yan general Zang Chu had followed Chu to rescue Zhao and had accompanied them into the passes. Therefore they installed him as King of Yan, with his capital at Ji.

sentences.zh: 徙齊王田市為膠東王。

translations.literal: Moved King Shi of Qi to become King of Jiaodong.
translations.idiomatic: They relocated King Shi of Qi to become King of Jiaodong.

sentences.zh: 齊將田都從共救趙，因從入關，故立都為齊王，都臨菑。

translations.literal: Qi general Tian Du followed together to rescue Zhao, moreover followed into the passes, therefore established Du as King of Qi, with capital at Linzi.
translations.idiomatic: Qi general Tian Du had joined the rescue of Zhao and accompanied them into the passes. Therefore they installed him as King of Qi, with his capital at Linzi.

sentences.zh: 故秦所滅齊王建孫田安，項羽方渡河救趙，田安下濟北數城，引其兵降項羽，故立安為濟北王，都博陽。

translations.literal: Formerly Qin destroyed Qi King Jian's grandson Tian An, Xiang Yu was just crossing the river to rescue Zhao, Tian An conquered several cities north of the Ji River, led his troops to surrender to Xiang Yu, therefore established An as King of Jibei, with capital at Boyang.
translations.idiomatic: Tian An, grandson of the Qi King Jian whom Qin had destroyed, conquered several cities north of the Ji River while Xiang Yu was crossing to rescue Zhao. He led his troops to surrender to Xiang Yu. Therefore they installed him as King of Jibei, with his capital at Boyang.

sentences.zh: 田榮者，數負項梁，又不肯將兵從楚擊秦，以故不封。

translations.literal: Tian Rong, repeatedly betrayed Xiang Liang, moreover refused to lead troops following Chu to attack Qin, for this reason was not enfeoffed.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong had repeatedly betrayed Xiang Liang and refused to lead troops to follow Chu in attacking Qin. For this reason, he was not enfeoffed.

sentences.zh: 成安君陳餘棄將印去，不從入關，然素聞其賢，有功於趙，聞其在南皮，故因環封三縣。

translations.literal: Lord Cheng'an Chen Yu abandoned his general's seal and departed, did not follow into the passes, yet long known for his worthiness, had merit in Zhao, heard he was in Nanpi, therefore provisionally enfeoffed three counties around it.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Cheng'an Chen Yu had abandoned his general's seal and left, refusing to follow into the passes. Yet he was long known for his worthiness and had merit in Zhao. Hearing he was in Nanpi, they provisionally enfeoffed him with three surrounding counties.

sentences.zh: 番君將梅鋗功多，故封十萬戶侯。

translations.literal: Lord of Fan's general Mei Dun achieved much merit, therefore enfeoffed as marquis of one hundred thousand households.
translations.idiomatic: The Lord of Fan's general Mei Dun had achieved great merit. Therefore he was enfeoffed as a marquis with one hundred thousand households.

sentences.zh: 項王自立為西楚霸王，王九郡，都彭城。

translations.literal: King Xiang self-established as Hegemon King of Western Chu, ruling nine commanderies, with capital at Pengcheng.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang established himself as Hegemon King of Western Chu, ruling nine commanderies, with his capital at Pengcheng.

translations.literal: King Xiang sent people to report the command to King Huai. King Huai said: 'As agreed.' He then honored King Huai as the Righteous Emperor. King Xiang wished to be king himself. He first enfeoffed the various generals and ministers as kings. He said: 'When the world initially began its difficulties, we temporarily established the feudal lords' descendants to attack Qin. Yet those who personally wore armor and wielded sharp weapons, who first began the matters and were exposed in the wilds for three years, who extinguished Qin and settled the world—all were through the strength of you various lords generals and ministers with me, Ji. The Righteous Emperor, though he has no merit, should therefore have his lands divided and be made king of them.' All the generals said: 'Good.' He then divided the world and established the various generals as marquises and kings. King Xiang and Fan Zeng suspected Liu Bang would take the world. They had already reconciled, but moreover hated to break the agreement and feared the feudal lords would rebel against him. They then secretly planned, saying: 'The Ba and Shu roads are dangerous. Qin's banished people all reside in Shu.' He then said: 'Ba and Shu are also Guanzhong territory.' Therefore he established Liu Bang as Han King, to rule Ba, Shu, and Hanzhong, with his capital at Nanzheng. He divided Guanzhong into three parts and enfeoffed Qin surrendered generals to block and bar the Han King. King Xiang then established Zhang Han as Yong King, to rule west of Xianyang, with his capital at Feiqiu. Chief Clerk Xin had formerly been a Queyang prison clerk and once shown virtue to Xiang Liang; Commandery Captain Dong Yi had originally advised Zhang Han to surrender to Chu. Therefore he established Sima Xin as Sai King, to rule from Xianyang east to the river, with his capital at Queyang; He established Dong Yi as Di King, to rule Shang commandery, with his capital at Gaonu. He moved King Wei Bao to become West Wei King, to rule Hedong, with his capital at Pingyang. Xiaqiu's Shen Yang was Zhang Er's favorite minister. He first submitted Henan commandery and welcomed Chu on the river. Therefore he established Shen Yang as Henan King, with his capital at Luoyang. King Han Cheng kept his old capital, with his capital at Yangdi. Zhao general Sima Ang pacified Henan and had merit several times. Therefore he established Ang as Yin King, to rule Henan, with his capital at Zhaoge. He moved King Zhao Xie to become Dai King. Zhao chancellor Zhang Er was originally worthy and moreover followed into the passes. Therefore he established Er as Changshan King, to rule Zhao territory, with his capital at Xiangguo. Lord Dangyang Qing Bu was a Chu general and constantly the champion. Therefore he established Bu as Jiujiang King, with his capital at Liu. Lord Po Wu Rui led the hundred Yue to assist the feudal lords and moreover followed into the passes. Therefore he established Rui as Hengshan King, with his capital at Zhu. The Righteous Emperor's supreme pillar of state Gong Ao led troops to strike Nan commandery. His merit was great, so he established Ao as Linjiang King, with his capital at Jiangling. He moved King Yan Han Guang to become Liaodong King. Yan general Zang Tu followed Chu to rescue Zhao and moreover followed into the passes. Therefore he established Tu as Yan King, with his capital at Ji. He moved King Qi Tian Shi to become Jiaodong King. Qi general Tian Du followed to rescue Zhao together and moreover followed into the passes. Therefore he established Du as Qi King, with his capital at Linzi. Tian An was the grandson of the Qi King Jian whom Qin had extinguished. Xiang Yu was just crossing the river to rescue Zhao when Tian An submitted several Jibei cities and led his troops to surrender to Xiang Yu. Therefore he established An as Jibei King, with his capital at Boyang. Tian Rong had several times betrayed Xiang Liang and moreover was not willing to lead troops to follow Chu in striking Qin. For this reason he was not enfeoffed. Lord Cheng'an Chen Yu abandoned his general's seal and left, did not follow into the passes. Yet he was originally known as worthy and had merit to Zhao. He heard he was at Nanpi, so accordingly he enfeoffed him with three surrounding counties. Lord Fan's general Mei Dun had great merit, so he enfeoffed him as marquis of one hundred thousand households. King Xiang self-established as Western Chu Hegemon King, ruling nine commanderies, with his capital at Pengcheng.

sentences.zh: 漢之元年四月，諸侯罷戲下，各就國。

translations.literal: In the fourth month of the first year of Han, the feudal lords departed from below Xi, each going to their kingdoms.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth month of the first year of Han, the feudal lords left the area below Xi and each returned to their kingdoms.

sentences.zh: 項王出之國，使人徙義帝，曰：「古之帝者地方千里，必居上游。」

translations.literal: King Xiang sent out from his kingdom, sent people to move the Righteous Emperor, saying: 'Ancient emperors had territories of a thousand li, must reside upstream.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang sent orders from his kingdom to relocate the Righteous Emperor, saying: 'Ancient emperors ruled territories of a thousand li and always resided upstream.'

sentences.zh: 乃使使徙義帝長沙郴縣。

translations.literal: Then sent envoys to move the Righteous Emperor to Chen county in Changsha.
translations.idiomatic: He then sent envoys to relocate the Righteous Emperor to Chen county in Changsha.

sentences.zh: 趣義帝行，其群臣稍稍背叛之，乃陰令衡山、臨江王擊殺之江中。

translations.literal: Urged the Righteous Emperor to travel, his ministers gradually deserted him, then secretly ordered the Kings of Hengshan and Linjiang to attack and kill him in the river.
translations.idiomatic: He urged the Righteous Emperor to proceed on his journey. His ministers gradually deserted him. Xiang Yu then secretly ordered the Kings of Hengshan and Linjiang to attack and kill him in the river.

sentences.zh: 韓王成無軍功，項王不使之國，與俱至彭城，廢以為侯，已又殺之。

translations.literal: King Cheng of Han had no military merit, King Xiang did not send him to his kingdom, brought him together to Pengcheng, demoted him to marquis, then again killed him.
translations.idiomatic: King Cheng of Han had no military merit. King Xiang did not allow him to go to his kingdom but brought him to Pengcheng, demoted him to marquis, and then killed him.

sentences.zh: 臧荼之國，因逐韓廣之遼東，廣弗聽，荼擊殺廣無終，

translations.literal: Zang Chu went to his kingdom, then pursued Han Guang to Liaodong, Guang did not listen, Chu attacked and killed Guang at Wuzhong,
translations.idiomatic: Zang Chu went to his kingdom and then pursued Han Guang to Liaodong. Han Guang refused to comply, so Zang Chu attacked and killed him at Wuzhong.

translations.literal: In Han's first year, fourth month, the feudal lords were dismissed from below Xi and each went to their states. King Xiang sent him out to his state and had people move the Righteous Emperor, saying: 'Ancient emperors had territories of a thousand li and must reside upstream.' He then sent envoys to move the Righteous Emperor to Chen county in Changsha. He urged the Righteous Emperor to go. His ministers gradually betrayed him one by one. He then secretly ordered the Hengshan and Linjiang Kings to strike and kill him in the Jiang River. King Han Cheng had no military merit. King Xiang did not make him go to his state. He brought him along to Pengcheng, abolished him to marquis, and then moreover killed him. Zang Tu went to his state and took advantage to expel Han Guang to Liaodong. Guang did not listen. Tu struck and killed Guang at Wuzhong,

sentences.zh: 田榮聞項羽徙齊王市膠東，而立齊將田都為齊王，乃大怒，不肯遣齊王之膠東，因以齊反，迎擊田都。

translations.literal: Tian Rong heard Xiang Yu moved Qi King Shi to Jiaodong, and established Qi general Tian Du as King of Qi, then greatly angered, refused to send the Qi king to Jiaodong, therefore with Qi rebelled, met and attacked Tian Du.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong learned that Xiang Yu had moved Qi King Shi to Jiaodong and installed Qi general Tian Du as King of Qi. He flew into a rage, refused to send the Qi king to Jiaodong, and led Qi in rebellion, attacking Tian Du.

sentences.zh: 田都走楚。

translations.literal: Tian Du fled to Chu.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Du escaped to Chu.

sentences.zh: 齊王市畏項王，乃亡之膠東就國。

translations.literal: Qi King Shi feared King Xiang, then fled to Jiaodong to take up his kingdom.
translations.idiomatic: Qi King Shi feared King Xiang and fled to Jiaodong to assume his kingship.

sentences.zh: 田榮怒，追擊殺之即墨。

translations.literal: Tian Rong angered, pursued and attacked, killed him at Jimo.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong, enraged, pursued and attacked him, killing Qi King Shi at Jimo.

sentences.zh: 榮因自立為齊王，而西殺擊濟北王田安，并王三齊。

translations.literal: Rong therefore self-established as King of Qi, and westward attacked and killed Jibei King Tian An, united and ruled the three Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong therefore proclaimed himself King of Qi. He attacked westward and killed Jibei King Tian An, uniting all three Qi regions under his rule.

sentences.zh: 榮與彭越將軍印，令反梁地。

translations.literal: Rong gave Peng Yue the general's seal, ordered him to rebel in Liang territory.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong gave Peng Yue a general's seal and ordered him to rebel in Liang territory.

sentences.zh: 陳餘陰使張同、夏說說齊王田榮曰：「項羽為天下宰，不平。

translations.literal: Chen Yu secretly sent Zhang Tong and Xia Yue to persuade Qi King Tian Rong saying: 'Xiang Yu acts as butcher of the world, not fair.
translations.idiomatic: Chen Yu secretly sent Zhang Tong and Xia Yue to persuade Qi King Tian Rong: 'Xiang Yu acts as the world's butcher. His actions are unfair.'

sentences.zh: 今盡王故王於醜地，而王其群臣諸將善地，逐其故主趙王，乃北居代，餘以為不可。

translations.literal: Now completely kings the former kings in bad lands, but kings his ministers and generals in good lands, drives out their former lord King of Zhao, makes him reside north in Dai, Yu considers it not right.
translations.idiomatic: Now he installs all the former kings in barren lands but gives his ministers and generals the fertile territories. He drives out their former lord, King of Zhao, and forces him to live in the north in Dai. I consider this unjust.'

sentences.zh: 聞大王起兵，且不聽不義，願大王資餘兵，請以擊常山，以復趙王，請以國為捍蔽。」

translations.literal: Heard Your Majesty raised troops, moreover does not listen to unrighteous matters, wish Your Majesty provide Yu with troops, request to attack Changshan, to restore the King of Zhao, request to use the kingdom as shield.'
translations.idiomatic: I hear Your Majesty has raised troops and refuses to heed injustice. I wish Your Majesty would provide me with troops to attack Changshan, restore the King of Zhao, and use my kingdom as a protective barrier.'

sentences.zh: 齊王許之，因遣兵之趙。

translations.literal: The Qi king agreed to it, therefore sent troops to Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Qi agreed and sent troops to Zhao.

sentences.zh: 陳餘悉發三縣兵，與齊并力擊常山，大破之。

translations.literal: Chen Yu mobilized all the troops from the three counties, joined with Qi in attacking Changshan, greatly defeating them.
translations.idiomatic: Chen Yu mobilized troops from all three counties and joined forces with Qi to attack Changshan, decisively defeating them.

sentences.zh: 張耳走歸漢。

translations.literal: Zhang Er fled and returned to Han.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Er fled back to Han.

sentences.zh: 陳餘迎故趙王歇於代，反之趙。

translations.literal: Chen Yu welcomed the former Zhao King Xie from Dai, returned him to Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: Chen Yu welcomed the former King Xie of Zhao from Dai and restored him to Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙王因立陳餘為代王。

translations.literal: The Zhao king therefore established Chen Yu as King of Dai.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Zhao then installed Chen Yu as King of Dai.

translations.literal: Tian Rong heard that Xiang Yu had moved King Qi Tian Shi to Jiaodong and established the Qi general Tian Du as Qi King. He then became greatly angered and was not willing to send King Qi to Jiaodong. He took advantage to rebel with Qi and welcomed the attack on Tian Du. Tian Du fled to Chu. King Qi Tian Shi feared King Xiang and then fled to Jiaodong to take his state. Tian Rong became angered and pursued and struck and killed him at Jimo. Rong took advantage to self-establish as Qi King, and to the west killed and struck Jibei King Tian An, uniting and ruling the three Qi territories. Rong gave Peng Yue the general's seal and ordered him to rebel in Liang territory. Chen Yu secretly sent Zhang Tong and Xia Shuo to persuade King Qi Tian Rong, saying: 'Xiang Yu is steward of the world, but it is not fair. Now he completely enfeoffs former kings in ugly territories, and enfeoffs his ministers and various generals in good territories. He expelled their former lord King Zhao, and moreover had him reside north in Dai. I, Yu, consider this not possible. I heard the great king has raised troops, and moreover does not listen to what is not righteous. I wish the great king would supply me, Yu, with troops. I request to strike Changshan, to restore King Zhao. I request to use the state as a shield and barrier.' King Qi permitted it and took advantage to send troops to Zhao. Chen Yu completely dispatched the three counties' troops and with Qi combined their strength to strike Changshan, greatly defeating it. Zhang Er fled and returned to Han. Chen Yu welcomed the former King Zhao Xie from Dai and returned him to Zhao. King Zhao took advantage to establish Chen Yu as Dai King.

sentences.zh: 是時，漢還定三秦。

translations.literal: At this time, Han returned and pacified the three Qin.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Han forces returned and pacified the three Qin regions.

sentences.zh: 項羽聞漢王皆已并關中，且東，齊、趙叛之：大怒。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu heard the Han king had already annexed all of Guanzhong, moreover was coming east, Qi and Zhao had rebelled against him: greatly angered.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu learned that the King of Han had annexed all of Guanzhong and was advancing eastward, while Qi and Zhao had rebelled against him. He flew into a rage.

sentences.zh: 乃以故吳令鄭昌為韓王，以距漢。

translations.literal: Then made the former Wu magistrate Zheng Chang King of Han, to resist Han.
translations.idiomatic: He then installed Zheng Chang, the former magistrate of Wu, as King of Han to block Han's advance.

sentences.zh: 令蕭公角等擊彭越。

translations.literal: Ordered Xiao Gongjiao and others to attack Peng Yue.
translations.idiomatic: He ordered Xiao Gongjiao and others to attack Peng Yue.

sentences.zh: 彭越敗蕭公角等。

translations.literal: Peng Yue defeated Xiao Gongjiao and others.
translations.idiomatic: Peng Yue defeated Xiao Gongjiao and his forces.

sentences.zh: 漢使張良徇韓，乃遺項王書曰：「漢王失職，欲得關中，如約即止，不敢東。」

translations.literal: Han sent Zhang Liang to pacify Han, then sent Xiang Yu a letter saying: 'The Han king has lost his position, wishes to obtain Guanzhong, if according to agreement then stops, dares not go east.'
translations.idiomatic: Han sent Zhang Liang to pacify the region of Han, then sent Xiang Yu a letter: 'The King of Han has been deprived of his rightful position. He wishes to regain Guanzhong. If we honor our original agreement, he will stop there and not advance eastward.'

sentences.zh: 又以齊、梁反書遺項王曰：「齊欲與趙并滅楚。」

translations.literal: Moreover sent Qi and Liang's rebellion letter to Xiang Yu saying: 'Qi wishes to join with Zhao to destroy Chu together.'
translations.idiomatic: Han also sent Xiang Yu letters from the rebellions in Qi and Liang: 'Qi intends to join forces with Zhao to destroy Chu.'

sentences.zh: 楚以此故無西意，而北擊齊。

translations.literal: Chu for this reason had no intention to go west, but north attacked Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Because of this, Chu had no intention of advancing west but turned north to attack Qi.

sentences.zh: 徵兵九江王布。

translations.literal: Conscripted troops from Jiujiang King Bu.
translations.idiomatic: He conscripted troops from Ying Bu, King of Jiujiang.

sentences.zh: 布稱疾不往，使將將數千人行。

translations.literal: Bu pleaded illness and did not go, sent a general leading several thousand to go.
translations.idiomatic: Ying Bu claimed illness and refused to go personally, but sent a general with several thousand troops.

sentences.zh: 項王由此怨布也。

translations.literal: King Xiang from this resented Bu.
translations.idiomatic: From this point on, King Xiang harbored resentment toward Ying Bu.

sentences.zh: 漢之二年冬，項羽遂北至城陽，田榮亦將兵會戰。

translations.literal: In the winter of the second year of Han, Xiang Yu then went north to Chengyang, Tian Rong also led troops to meet in battle.
translations.idiomatic: In the winter of the second year of Han, Xiang Yu marched north to Chengyang, where Tian Rong also led troops to engage him in battle.

sentences.zh: 田榮不勝，走至平原，平原民殺之。

translations.literal: Tian Rong could not prevail, fled to Pingyuan, the Pingyuan people killed him.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong was defeated and fled to Pingyuan, where the local people killed him.

sentences.zh: 遂北燒夷齊城郭室屋，皆阬田榮降卒，系虜其老弱婦女。

translations.literal: Then north burned and destroyed Qi's city walls and houses, all buried alive Tian Rong's surrendered soldiers, bound and captured their old and weak women.
translations.idiomatic: He then marched north, burning and destroying Qi's cities and buildings. He massacred all of Tian Rong's surrendered troops and took captive their elderly, weak, and womenfolk.

sentences.zh: 徇齊至北海，多所殘滅。

translations.literal: Pacified Qi reaching Beihai, did much destruction and extermination.
translations.idiomatic: He pacified the region of Qi all the way to Beihai, causing widespread destruction and slaughter.

sentences.zh: 齊人相聚而叛之。

translations.literal: The Qi people gathered together and rebelled against him.
translations.idiomatic: The people of Qi gathered in groups and rebelled against Xiang Yu.

sentences.zh: 於是田榮弟田橫收齊亡卒得數萬人，反城陽。

translations.literal: Thereupon Tian Rong's younger brother Tian Heng gathered Qi's scattered soldiers getting several ten thousand people, rebelled at Chengyang.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong's younger brother Tian Heng then gathered tens of thousands of Qi's scattered troops and launched a rebellion at Chengyang.

sentences.zh: 項王因留，連戰未能下。

translations.literal: King Xiang therefore stayed, fought continuously but could not conquer.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang therefore remained there, fighting continuous battles but unable to take the city.

translations.literal: At this time, Han returned and pacified the three Qin territories. Xiang Yu heard that Han King had already united all of Guanzhong and moreover was advancing east, and that Qi and Zhao had rebelled against him. He became greatly angered. He then made the former Wu magistrate Zheng Chang Han King, to resist Han. He ordered Xiao Gong Jiao and others to strike Peng Yue. Peng Yue defeated Xiao Gong Jiao and others. Han sent Zhang Liang to tour Han, then sent King Xiang a letter saying: 'Han King has lost his position. He wishes to get Guanzhong. As per the agreement, he will then stop and not dare to advance east.' He again sent King Xiang letters about Qi and Liang's rebellion, saying: 'Qi wishes to unite with Zhao and extinguish Chu.' Chu, for this reason, had no intention to go west, and instead struck north at Qi. He conscripted troops from Jiujiang King Bu. Bu claimed illness and did not go. He had a general lead several thousand people who went. King Xiang from this resented Bu. In Han's second year, winter, Xiang Yu then went north to Chengyang. Tian Rong also led troops to assemble for battle. Tian Rong was not victorious. He fled to Pingyuan, where the Pingyuan people killed him. He then went north and burned and razed Qi's city walls and houses. He buried alive all of Tian Rong's surrendered soldiers and bound and captured their old, weak, and women. He toured Qi and arrived at Beihai, destroying and extinguishing much. The Qi people gathered together and rebelled against him. Therefore Tian Rong's younger brother Tian Heng gathered Qi's scattered soldiers, getting several ten thousand people, and rebelled at Chengyang. King Xiang took advantage to stay. Continuous battles could not conquer it.

sentences.zh: 春，漢王部五諸侯兵，凡五十六萬人，東伐楚。

translations.literal: Spring, the Han king commanded the five feudal lords' troops, altogether five hundred sixty thousand people, east attacked Chu.
translations.idiomatic: In spring, the King of Han commanded the combined armies of five allied lords—totaling 560,000 men—and launched an eastward campaign against Chu.

sentences.zh: 項王聞之，即令諸將擊齊，而自以精兵三萬人南從魯出胡陵。

translations.literal: King Xiang heard this, immediately ordered the various generals to attack Qi, and himself with elite troops thirty thousand people south from Lu emerged at Huling.
translations.idiomatic: Upon hearing this, King Xiang immediately ordered his generals to continue attacking Qi while he himself led 30,000 elite troops south from Lu, emerging at Huling.

sentences.zh: 四月，漢皆已入彭城，收其貨寶美人，日置酒高會。

translations.literal: Fourth month, Han all had already entered Pengcheng, collected its goods, treasures, and beauties, daily set wine and grand gatherings.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth month, Han forces had completely occupied Pengcheng. They collected all the riches, treasures, and beautiful women. Every day they held lavish drinking parties and celebrations.

sentences.zh: 項王乃西從蕭，晨擊漢軍而東，至彭城，日中，大破漢軍。

translations.literal: King Xiang then west from Xiao, at dawn attacked the Han army and went east, reached Pengcheng, at noon, greatly defeated the Han army.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang marched west from Xiao, attacked the Han army at dawn, and advanced eastward. By noon he had reached Pengcheng and decisively defeated the Han forces.

sentences.zh: 漢軍皆走，相隨入穀、泗水，殺漢卒十餘萬人。

translations.literal: Han army all fled, following each other entered the Gu and Si rivers, killed Han soldiers more than ten ten thousand people.
translations.idiomatic: The Han army fled in panic, crowding into the Gu and Si Rivers. Xiang Yu's forces killed over 100,000 Han soldiers.
