sentences.zh: 漢卒皆南走山，楚又追擊至靈壁東睢水上。

translations.literal: Han soldiers all south fled to the mountains, Chu again pursued and attacked to east of Lingbi on the Sui River.
translations.idiomatic: The Han soldiers all fled south into the mountains. The Chu forces pursued them relentlessly, attacking as far east as Lingbi on the Sui River.

sentences.zh: 漢軍卻，為楚所擠，多殺，漢卒十餘萬人皆入睢水，睢水為之不流。

translations.literal: Han army retreated, squeezed by Chu, much killing, Han soldiers more than ten ten thousand people all entered the Sui River, the Sui River because of this did not flow.
translations.idiomatic: The Han army retreated, pressed hard by the Chu forces. In the slaughter that followed, over 100,000 Han soldiers plunged into the Sui River, clogging it so completely that the river stopped flowing.

sentences.zh: 圍漢王三匝。

translations.literal: Surrounded the Han king three circuits.
translations.idiomatic: The Chu forces encircled the King of Han three times.

sentences.zh: 於是大風從西北而起，折木發屋，揚沙石，窈冥晝晦，逢迎楚軍。

translations.literal: Thereupon great wind from northwest arose, broke trees and lifted roofs, raised sand and stones, dark and gloomy daylight turned to darkness, met the Chu army.
translations.idiomatic: Suddenly a great wind arose from the northwest, snapping trees and tearing off roofs, whipping up sand and stones. Day turned to dark gloom, and the wind struck the Chu army head-on.

sentences.zh: 楚軍大亂，壞散，而漢王乃得與數十騎遁去，欲過沛，收家室而西；

translations.literal: Chu army greatly disordered, broken and scattered, and the Han king then was able with several ten horsemen to escape, wished to pass through Pei, collect family and go west;
translations.idiomatic: The Chu army fell into great confusion and scattered in disarray. The King of Han escaped with only a few dozen horsemen. He wanted to pass through Pei, gather his family, and flee westward.

sentences.zh: 楚亦使人追之沛，取漢王家：家皆亡，不與漢王相見。

translations.literal: Chu also sent people to pursue to Pei, seize the Han king's family: the family all fled, did not meet with the Han king.
translations.idiomatic: The Chu forces also sent men to pursue him to Pei and seize his family. But his family had all fled and did not meet with the King of Han.

sentences.zh: 漢王道逢得孝惠、魯元，乃載行。

translations.literal: Han king on the road encountered and obtained Xiaohui, Lu Yuan, then loaded and traveled.
translations.idiomatic: Along the way, the King of Han encountered and rescued his son Xiaohui and daughter Lu Yuan, then took them with him as he fled.

sentences.zh: 楚騎追漢王，漢王急，推墮孝惠、魯元車下，滕公常下收載之。

translations.literal: Chu cavalry pursued the Han king, Han king urgent, pushed and dropped Xiaohui, Lu Yuan under the cart, Teng Gong often descended and collected and loaded them.
translations.idiomatic: Chu cavalry pursued the King of Han relentlessly. In desperation, he pushed his son Xiaohui and daughter Lu Yuan off the cart. Teng Gong repeatedly dismounted to pick them up and put them back on.

sentences.zh: 如是者三。

translations.literal: Like this three times.
translations.idiomatic: This happened three times.

sentences.zh: 曰：「雖急不可以驅，柰何棄之？」

translations.literal: Said: 'Though urgent cannot drive fast, how can abandon them?'
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'Even in desperate flight, we cannot abandon them. How could we leave them behind?'

sentences.zh: 於是遂得脫。

translations.literal: Thereupon then was able to escape.
translations.idiomatic: Thus they managed to escape.

sentences.zh: 求太公、呂后不相遇。

translations.literal: Sought Taigong, Empress Lu, did not meet.
translations.idiomatic: He searched for his father Taigong and Empress Lu but could not find them.

sentences.zh: 審食其從太公、呂后閒行，求漢王，反遇楚軍。

translations.literal: Shen Yiji followed Taigong, Empress Lu in secret travel, sought the Han king, instead encountered Chu army.
translations.idiomatic: Shen Yiji was traveling secretly with Taigong and Empress Lu, searching for the King of Han. Instead, they encountered Chu troops.

sentences.zh: 楚軍遂與歸，報項王，項王常置軍中。

translations.literal: Chu army then gave them back, reported to King Xiang, King Xiang constantly placed them in the army.
translations.idiomatic: The Chu army then returned them safely and reported to King Xiang, who kept them in his military camp.

translations.literal: In spring, Han King commanded the five feudal lords' troops, altogether five hundred sixty thousand people, and attacked east against Chu. King Xiang heard it and immediately ordered the various generals to strike Qi, while he himself, with thirty thousand elite troops, went south from Lu and emerged at Huling. In the fourth month, Han had all entered Pengcheng. They collected its goods, treasures, and beauties. Daily they arranged wine and grand gatherings. King Xiang then came west from Xiao. In the morning he struck the Han army and went east. He arrived at Pengcheng at noon and greatly defeated the Han army. The Han army all fled, following each other into the Gu and Si rivers. They killed more than one hundred thousand Han soldiers. The Han soldiers all fled south to the mountains. Chu again pursued and struck them east of Lingbi on the Sui River. The Han army retreated, squeezed by Chu, much killed. More than one hundred thousand Han soldiers all entered the Sui River. The Sui River because of this did not flow. They surrounded Han King three times around. Therefore a great wind arose from the northwest. It broke trees and tore roofs. It raised sand and stones. It darkened midday into darkness. It met and welcomed the Chu army. The Chu army became greatly disordered and ruined and scattered. Han King then got to escape and go with several dozen riders. He wished to pass through Pei, collect his family, and go west; Chu also sent people to pursue him to Pei and take Han King's family. The family had all fled and did not meet with Han King. Han King encountered Xiao Hui and Lu Yuan on the road. He then carried them along. Chu cavalry pursued Han King. Han King was urgent. He pushed Xiao Hui and Lu Yuan to fall below the cart. Teng Gong often descended and collected and carried them. Like this three times. He said: 'Though urgent, we cannot hurry. How can we abandon them?' Therefore he then got to escape. He sought Tai Gong and Lu Hou but did not meet them. Shen Yiqi followed Tai Gong and Lu Hou as they stealthily went seeking Han King. Instead they encountered the Chu army. The Chu army then returned with them and reported to King Xiang. King Xiang often placed them in the army camp.

sentences.zh: 是時呂后兄周呂侯為漢將兵居下邑，漢王閒往從之，稍稍收其士卒。

translations.literal: At this time Empress Lu's elder brother Marquis Zhou Lu commanded Han troops stationed at Xiayi, Han king secretly went to join him, gradually gathered his soldiers.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Empress Lu's brother Marquis Zhou Lu commanded Han troops stationed at Xiayi. The King of Han secretly went to join him and gradually rallied the scattered soldiers.

sentences.zh: 至滎陽，諸敗軍皆會，蕭何亦發關中老弱未傅悉詣滎陽，復大振。

translations.literal: Reached Xingyang, the various defeated armies all assembled, Xiao He also mobilized Guanzhong elderly and weak not yet registered all went to Xingyang, again greatly flourished.
translations.idiomatic: He reached Xingyang where all the defeated armies assembled. Xiao He also mobilized the elderly and weak from Guanzhong who had not yet been registered for service, sending them all to Xingyang. Han's strength was greatly restored.

sentences.zh: 楚起於彭城，常乘勝逐北，與漢戰滎陽南京、索閒，漢敗楚，楚以故不能過滎陽而西。

translations.literal: Chu arose from Pengcheng, constantly took advantage of victory to pursue the fleeing, fought with Han at Xingyang south of the capital, Suo between, Han defeated Chu, Chu therefore could not pass Xingyang and go west.
translations.idiomatic: Chu's campaign began at Pengcheng, and they constantly pursued fleeing enemies on the momentum of victory. They fought Han forces south of the capital at Xingyang and in the region of Suo. Han defeated Chu there, so Chu could not advance past Xingyang to the west.

translations.literal: At this time, Lu Hou's brother Zhou Lu Hou was leading troops for Han and residing at Xiayi. Han King stealthily went and followed him. Gradually he gathered his soldiers. He arrived at Xingyang. The various defeated armies all assembled. Xiao He also dispatched Guanzhong's old and weak who were not registered and had them all go to Xingyang. He again greatly flourished. Chu arose from Pengcheng. They often rode on victory and pursued north. They fought with Han at Xingyang's southern capital and between Su. Han defeated Chu. Therefore Chu could not pass Xingyang and go west.

sentences.zh: 項王之救彭城，追漢王至滎陽，田橫亦得收齊，立田榮子廣為齊王。

translations.literal: King Xiang's rescue of Pengcheng, pursued Han king to Xingyang, Tian Heng also was able to gather Qi, established Tian Rong's son Guang as King of Qi.
translations.idiomatic: While King Xiang was rescuing Pengcheng and pursuing the Han king to Xingyang, Tian Heng was able to rally Qi and install Tian Rong's son Guang as King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 漢王之敗彭城，諸侯皆復與楚而背漢。

translations.literal: Han king's defeat at Pengcheng, the feudal lords all again joined with Chu and turned against Han.
translations.idiomatic: After the Han king's defeat at Pengcheng, all the feudal lords switched back to Chu's side and abandoned Han.

sentences.zh: 漢軍滎陽，筑甬道屬之河，以取敖倉粟。

translations.literal: Han army at Xingyang, built a covered walkway connecting to the river, to take Aocang grain.
translations.idiomatic: The Han army at Xingyang built a covered walkway connecting to the Yellow River to transport grain from the Aocang granary.

sentences.zh: 漢之三年，項王數侵奪漢甬道，漢王食乏，恐，請和，割滎陽以西為漢。

translations.literal: Han third year, King Xiang repeatedly invaded and seized Han's covered walkway, Han king provisions lacking, feared, requested peace, ceded Xingyang west to Han.
translations.idiomatic: In the third year of Han, King Xiang repeatedly attacked and seized Han's covered walkway. The Han king ran short of supplies and, fearing defeat, sued for peace, ceding all territory west of Xingyang to Han.

translations.literal: King Xiang relieved Pengcheng and pursued Han King to Xingyang. Tian Heng also got to gather Qi and established Tian Rong's son Guang as Qi King. Han King was defeated at Pengcheng. The feudal lords all again sided with Chu and turned against Han. The Han army was at Xingyang. They built a covered road connecting to the river to take grain from the Ao granary. In Han's third year, King Xiang several times invaded and seized Han's covered road. Han King lacked food and feared. He requested peace and divided Xingyang west as Han territory.

sentences.zh: 項王欲聽之。

translations.literal: King Xiang wished to listen to it.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang was inclined to accept the peace terms.

sentences.zh: 歷陽侯范增曰：「漢易與耳，今釋弗取，後必悔之。」

translations.literal: Marquis of Liyang Fan Zeng said: 'Han is easy to deal with, now release without taking, later must regret it.'
translations.idiomatic: Marquis of Liyang Fan Zeng said: 'Han is easy to defeat. If we let them go now without destroying them, we'll surely regret it later.'

sentences.zh: 項王乃與范增急圍滎陽。

translations.literal: King Xiang then with Fan Zeng urgently besieged Xingyang.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then joined Fan Zeng in urgently besieging Xingyang.

sentences.zh: 漢王患之，乃用陳平計閒項王。

translations.literal: Han king worried about it, then used Chen Ping's plan to sow discord in King Xiang.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king was troubled by this and adopted Chen Ping's plan to sow dissension between Xiang Yu and his advisors.

sentences.zh: 項王使者來，為太牢具，舉欲進之。

translations.literal: King Xiang's envoy came, prepared a grand feast, raised it wishing to present it.
translations.idiomatic: An envoy from King Xiang arrived. They prepared a grand feast and raised their cups, intending to present it.

sentences.zh: 見使者，詳驚愕曰：「吾以為亞父使者，乃反項王使者。」

translations.literal: Saw the envoy, pretended to be shocked and astonished, said: 'I thought it was the Secondary Father's envoy, but instead it is King Xiang's envoy.'
translations.idiomatic: When he saw the envoy, he pretended to be shocked: 'I thought this was an envoy from the Secondary Father, but it's actually King Xiang's envoy.'

sentences.zh: 更持去，以惡食食項王使者。

translations.literal: Changed and took away, fed King Xiang's envoy with inferior food.
translations.idiomatic: They switched it out and served King Xiang's envoy inferior food instead.

sentences.zh: 使者歸報項王，項王乃疑范增與漢有私，稍奪之權。

translations.literal: The envoy returned and reported to King Xiang, King Xiang then suspected Fan Zeng had private dealings with Han, gradually stripped him of authority.
translations.idiomatic: The envoy returned and reported to King Xiang. King Xiang then suspected that Fan Zeng was secretly collaborating with Han and gradually stripped him of his authority.

sentences.zh: 范增大怒，曰：「天下事大定矣，君王自為之。

translations.literal: Fan Zeng greatly angered, said: 'The world's affairs are largely settled, Your Majesty do it yourself.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Zeng flew into a rage: 'The empire's affairs are largely settled now. Your Majesty can handle them yourself.'

sentences.zh: 願賜骸骨歸卒伍。」

translations.literal: Wish to grant my old bones to return to the ranks.'
translations.idiomatic: Please allow this old man to retire to the ranks of common soldiers.'

sentences.zh: 項王許之。

translations.literal: King Xiang permitted it.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang granted his request.

sentences.zh: 行未至彭城，疽發背而死。

translations.literal: Journey not yet reaching Pengcheng, carbuncle erupted on back and died.
translations.idiomatic: Before reaching Pengcheng, Fan Zeng died when a carbuncle erupted on his back.

translations.literal: King Xiang wished to listen to it. Lord Liyang Fan Zeng said: 'Han is easy to deal with. Now if we release and do not take them, later we must regret it.' King Xiang then with Fan Zeng urgently surrounded Xingyang. Han King was worried by it. He then used Chen Ping's plan to sow discord with King Xiang. King Xiang's envoy came. They prepared a great sacrificial feast and raised it, wishing to present it. He saw the envoy and pretended to be startled and astonished, saying: 'I thought it was Yafu's envoy, but instead it is King Xiang's envoy.' He again held and went, feeding King Xiang's envoy with inferior food. The envoy returned and reported to King Xiang. King Xiang then suspected Fan Zeng had private dealings with Han and gradually seized his authority. Fan Zeng was greatly angered and said: 'World affairs are greatly settled. Lord king, do it yourself. I wish to be granted my remains and return to the common soldier ranks.' King Xiang permitted it. He traveled but had not yet arrived at Pengcheng when an ulcer erupted on his back and he died.

sentences.zh: 漢將紀信說漢王曰：「事已急矣，請為王誑楚為王，王可以閒出。」

translations.literal: Han general Ji Xin advised the Han king saying: 'The situation is already urgent, allow me to deceive Chu by posing as king, Your Majesty can secretly escape.'
translations.idiomatic: Han general Ji Xin advised the Han king: 'The situation is desperate. Let me impersonate you to deceive the Chu forces. You can slip away in secret.'

sentences.zh: 於是漢王夜出女子滎陽東門被甲二千人，楚兵四面擊之。

translations.literal: Thereupon the Han king at night sent out women from Xingyang east gate wearing armor two thousand people, Chu troops attacked them from four sides.
translations.idiomatic: That night, the Han king sent two thousand women wearing armor out through Xingyang's east gate. The Chu troops attacked them from all sides.

sentences.zh: 紀信乘黃屋車，傅左纛，曰：「城中食盡，漢王降。」

translations.literal: Ji Xin rode the yellow-roofed carriage, attached left banner, said: 'City food exhausted, Han king surrenders.'
translations.idiomatic: Ji Xin rode in the imperial yellow carriage with the left banner attached and announced: 'The city has run out of food. The King of Han surrenders.'

sentences.zh: 楚軍皆呼萬歲。

translations.literal: Chu army all called out 'Ten thousand years.'
translations.idiomatic: The Chu army all shouted 'Long live the emperor!'

sentences.zh: 漢王亦與數十騎從城西門出，走成皋。

translations.literal: Han king also with several ten horsemen from city west gate went out, fled to Chenggao.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king also slipped out through the west gate with a few dozen horsemen and fled to Chenggao.

sentences.zh: 項王見紀信，問：「漢王安在？」

translations.literal: King Xiang saw Ji Xin, asked: 'Where is the Han king?'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang saw Ji Xin and asked: 'Where is the King of Han?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「漢王已出矣。」

translations.literal: Said: 'The Han king has already gone out.'
translations.idiomatic: He replied: 'The King of Han has already escaped.'

sentences.zh: 項王燒殺紀信。

translations.literal: King Xiang burned and killed Ji Xin.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang had Ji Xin burned alive.

translations.literal: Han general Ji Xin advised Han King, saying: 'Matters are already urgent. Please allow me to deceive Chu by posing as king. The king can then stealthily leave.' Therefore Han King at night sent out women through Xingyang's east gate, armored with two thousand people. Chu troops struck them from four sides. Ji Xin rode the yellow-canopied chariot and attached the left banner, saying: 'The city has exhausted its food. Han King surrenders.' The Chu army all called 'ten thousand years.' Han King also with several dozen riders went out the city's west gate and fled to Chenggao. King Xiang saw Ji Xin and asked: 'Where is Han King?' He said: 'Han King has already left.' King Xiang burned and killed Ji Xin.

sentences.zh: 漢王使御史大夫周苛、樅公、魏豹守滎陽。

translations.literal: Han king sent Imperial Secretary Zhou Ke, Marquis Cong, Wei Bao to defend Xingyang.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king left Imperial Secretary Zhou Ke, Marquis Cong, and Wei Bao to defend Xingyang.

sentences.zh: 周苛、樅公謀曰：「反國之王，難與守城。」

translations.literal: Zhou Ke, Marquis Cong plotted saying: 'A king who has turned against his kingdom, difficult to defend the city with.'
translations.idiomatic: Zhou Ke and Marquis Cong conspired: 'A king who has betrayed his own kingdom is difficult to defend a city with.'

sentences.zh: 乃共殺魏豹。

translations.literal: Then together killed Wei Bao.
translations.idiomatic: They then killed Wei Bao together.

sentences.zh: 楚下滎陽城，生得周苛。

translations.literal: Chu conquered Xingyang city, captured Zhou Ke alive.
translations.idiomatic: Chu conquered Xingyang and captured Zhou Ke alive.

sentences.zh: 項王謂周苛曰：「為我將，我以公為上將軍，封三萬戶。」

translations.literal: King Xiang told Zhou Ke: 'Serve as my general, I will make you Supreme General, enfeoff with thirty thousand households.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang told Zhou Ke: 'Serve as my general and I'll make you Supreme Commander, enfeoffing you with thirty thousand households.'

sentences.zh: 周苛罵曰：「若不趣降漢，漢今虜若，若非漢敵也。」

translations.literal: Zhou Ke cursed saying: 'You do not quickly surrender to Han, Han now captures you alive, you are not Han's enemy.'
translations.idiomatic: Zhou Ke cursed: 'If you don't surrender to Han quickly, Han will capture you alive. You're no enemy of Han's.'

sentences.zh: 項王怒，烹周苛，井殺樅公。

translations.literal: King Xiang angered, boiled Zhou Ke, threw Marquis Cong into a well and killed him.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang flew into a rage. He had Zhou Ke boiled alive and threw Marquis Cong down a well to his death.

translations.literal: Han King made Imperial Secretary Zhou Ke, Cong Gong, and Wei Bao defend Xingyang. Zhou Ke and Cong Gong plotted, saying: 'A king from a rebel state is difficult to defend the city with.' They then together killed Wei Bao. Chu conquered Xingyang city and captured Zhou Ke alive. King Xiang said to Zhou Ke: 'Be my general. I will make you supreme general and enfeoff you with thirty thousand households.' Zhou Ke cursed and said: 'If you do not quickly surrender to Han, Han will now capture you. You are no enemy of Han.' King Xiang was angered. He boiled Zhou Ke and killed Cong Gong by casting him into a well.

sentences.zh: 漢王之出滎陽，南走宛、葉，得九江王布，行收兵，復入保成皋。

translations.literal: Han king's departure from Xingyang, south fled to Wan, Ye, obtained Jiujiang King Bu, along the way gathered troops, again entered and defended Chenggao.
translations.idiomatic: After leaving Xingyang, the Han king fled south to Wan and Ye. He obtained the allegiance of Ying Bu, King of Jiujiang, gathered troops along the way, and re-entered Chenggao for defense.

sentences.zh: 漢之四年，項王進兵圍成皋。

translations.literal: Han fourth year, King Xiang advanced troops to besiege Chenggao.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth year of Han, King Xiang advanced his troops and besieged Chenggao.

sentences.zh: 漢王逃，獨與滕公出成皋北門，渡河走修武，從張耳、韓信軍。

translations.literal: Han king fled, alone with Teng Gong went out Chenggao north gate, crossed river fled to Xiuwu, joined Zhang Er, Han Xin army.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king fled, going out Chenggao's north gate alone with Teng Gong. They crossed the Yellow River and fled to Xiuwu, where they joined Zhang Er and Han Xin's army.

sentences.zh: 諸將稍稍得出成皋，從漢王。

translations.literal: The various generals gradually were able to go out from Chenggao, followed the Han king.
translations.idiomatic: The various generals gradually managed to escape from Chenggao and joined the Han king.

sentences.zh: 楚遂拔成皋，欲西。

translations.literal: Chu then conquered Chenggao, wished to go west.
translations.idiomatic: Chu then conquered Chenggao and prepared to advance westward.

sentences.zh: 漢使兵距之鞏，令其不得西。

translations.literal: Han sent troops to resist them at Gong, caused them not to be able to go west.
translations.idiomatic: Han sent troops to block them at Gong county, preventing their westward advance.

translations.literal: After Han King left Xingyang, he fled south to Wan and Ye. He got Jiujiang King Bu, gathered troops en route, and again entered to defend Chenggao. In Han's fourth year, King Xiang advanced his troops and surrounded Chenggao. Han King fled. Alone with Teng Gong, he went out Chenggao's north gate, crossed the river, fled to Xiuwu, and followed Zhang Er and Han Xin's army. The various generals gradually got out of Chenggao and followed Han King. Chu then captured Chenggao and wished to go west. Han sent troops to resist them at Gong, preventing them from going west.

sentences.zh: 是時，彭越渡河擊楚東阿，殺楚將軍薛公。

translations.literal: At this time, Peng Yue crossed the river to attack Chu at Dong'e, killed Chu general Xue Gong.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Peng Yue crossed the river and attacked Chu forces at Dong'e, killing the Chu general Xue Gong.

sentences.zh: 項王乃自東擊彭越。

translations.literal: King Xiang then personally went east to attack Peng Yue.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then personally led troops east to attack Peng Yue.

sentences.zh: 漢王得淮陰侯兵，欲渡河南。

translations.literal: Han king obtained Marquis of Huaiyin troops, wished to cross south of the river.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king obtained Han Xin's troops and wanted to cross south of the Yellow River.

sentences.zh: 鄭忠說漢王，乃止壁河內。

translations.literal: Zheng Zhong advised the Han king, then stopped and fortified in Henan.
translations.idiomatic: Zheng Zhong advised the Han king, who then stopped and established fortifications in Henan.

sentences.zh: 使劉賈將兵佐彭越，燒楚積聚。

translations.literal: Sent Liu Jia to lead troops to assist Peng Yue, burn Chu grain stores.
translations.idiomatic: He sent Liu Jia with troops to assist Peng Yue and burn Chu's grain supplies.

sentences.zh: 項王東擊破之，走彭越。

translations.literal: King Xiang east attacked and defeated them, put Peng Yue to flight.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang attacked east and defeated them, forcing Peng Yue to flee.

sentences.zh: 漢王則引兵渡河，復取成皋，軍廣武，就敖倉食。

translations.literal: Han king then led troops to cross the river, again took Chenggao, stationed army at Guangwu, approached Aocang to eat.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king then led his troops across the river, recaptured Chenggao, stationed his army at Guangwu, and drew supplies from the Aocang granary.

sentences.zh: 項王已定東海來，西，與漢俱臨廣武而軍，相守數月。

translations.literal: King Xiang having pacified Donghai came west, together with Han both faced Guangwu and stationed armies, confronted each other for several months.
translations.idiomatic: After pacifying Donghai, King Xiang came west. He and Han both stationed their armies facing Guangwu and confronted each other for several months.

translations.literal: At this time, Peng Yue crossed the river and struck Chu at Dong'e, killing Chu general Xue Gong. King Xiang then personally went east to strike Peng Yue. Han King got Marquis Huaiyin's troops and wished to cross south of the river. Zheng Zhong advised Han King, and he then stopped and fortified Henan. He sent Liu Jia to lead troops and assist Peng Yue, burning Chu's stored supplies. King Xiang went east and struck and defeated them, making Peng Yue flee. Han King then led his troops across the river, again took Chenggao, stationed his army at Guangwu, and approached the Ao granary for food. King Xiang, having already pacified Donghai, came west. With Han they both faced Guangwu and stationed their armies, mutually defending for several months.

sentences.zh: 當此時，彭越數反梁地，絕楚糧食，項王患之。

translations.literal: At this time, Peng Yue repeatedly rebelled in Liang territory, cut off Chu grain supplies, King Xiang worried about it.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Peng Yue repeatedly rebelled in Liang territory and cut off Chu's grain supplies. King Xiang was greatly troubled by this.

sentences.zh: 為高俎，置太公其上，告漢王曰：「今不急下，吾烹太公。」

translations.literal: Made a high chopping block, placed Taigong on it, told Han king: 'Now if not quickly surrender, I will boil Taigong.'
translations.idiomatic: He built a high chopping block, placed Liu Bang's father Taigong on it, and sent word to the Han king: 'Surrender quickly or I'll boil your father alive.'

sentences.zh: 漢王曰：「吾與項羽俱北面受命懷王，曰『約為兄弟』，吾翁即若翁，必欲烹而翁，則幸分我一桮羹。」

translations.literal: Han king said: 'I and Xiang Yu both faced north to receive commands from King Huai, said "agreed to be brothers", my father is your father, if must boil your father, then fortunately divide me one cup of broth.'
translations.idiomatic: The Han king replied: 'Xiang Yu and I both bowed to King Huai and swore brotherhood. My father is your father too. If you must boil him, please save me a cup of the soup.'

sentences.zh: 項王怒，欲殺之。

translations.literal: King Xiang angered, wished to kill him.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang flew into a rage and wanted to kill him.

sentences.zh: 項伯曰：「天下事未可知，且為天下者不顧家，雖殺之無益，只益禍耳。」

translations.literal: Xiang Bo said: 'World affairs not yet knowable, moreover one who contends for the empire does not care about family, though kill him no benefit, only increases disaster.'
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Bo said: 'The outcome of the empire is still uncertain. Besides, those who contend for the world don't care about family. Killing him would do no good and only bring more disaster.'

sentences.zh: 項王從之。

translations.literal: King Xiang followed it.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang heeded his advice.

translations.literal: At this time, Peng Yue several times rebelled in Liang territory, cutting off Chu's grain and food. King Xiang was worried by it. He made a high chopping block and placed Tai Gong on it. He told Han King: 'If you do not quickly surrender now, I will boil Tai Gong.' Han King said: 'Xiang Yu and I both faced north and received commands from King Huai, agreeing to be brothers. My father is your father. If you must boil your father, then luckily divide me one cup of the broth.' King Xiang was angered and wished to kill him. Xiang Bo said: 'World affairs are not yet knowable. Moreover, one who contends for the world does not consider family. Though you kill him, it is not beneficial. It only increases calamity.' King Xiang followed it.

sentences.zh: 楚漢久相持未決，丁壯苦軍旅，老弱罷轉漕。

translations.literal: Chu Han long confronted without decision, able-bodied suffered military service, old weak exhausted transporting supplies.
translations.idiomatic: Chu and Han had been locked in stalemate for a long time without resolution. The able-bodied suffered from military service while the old and weak were exhausted from transporting supplies.

sentences.zh: 項王謂漢王曰：「天下匈匈數歲者，徒以吾兩人耳，願與漢王挑戰決雌雄，毋徒苦天下之民父子為也。」

translations.literal: King Xiang told Han king: 'The world in chaos several years, only because of us two people, wish to challenge Han king to decide male-female, do not vainly make the world's people fathers and sons suffer.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang told the Han king: 'The empire has been in chaos for years all because of the two of us. I wish to challenge you to single combat to determine the victor. Let's not make the people of the world suffer needlessly.'

sentences.zh: 漢王笑謝曰：「吾寧鬬智，不能鬬力。」

translations.literal: Han king laughing declined: 'I rather fight wisdom, cannot fight strength.'
translations.idiomatic: The Han king laughed and declined: 'I'd rather compete with wits than with brute strength.'

sentences.zh: 項王令壯士出挑戰。

translations.literal: King Xiang ordered brave warriors to go out and challenge.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang ordered his champions to come out and issue challenges.

sentences.zh: 漢有善騎射者樓煩，楚挑戰三合，樓煩輒射殺之。

translations.literal: Han had skilled horseman archer Lou Fan, Chu challenged three rounds, Lou Fan immediately shot and killed them.
translations.idiomatic: Han had a skilled archer named Lou Fan. When Chu issued three challenges, Lou Fan shot and killed each challenger.

sentences.zh: 項王大怒，乃自被甲持戟挑戰。

translations.literal: King Xiang greatly angered, then personally donned armor grasped halberd challenged.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang was furious and personally donned armor, grasped his halberd, and issued a challenge.

sentences.zh: 樓煩欲射之，項王瞋目叱之，樓煩目不敢視，手不敢發，遂走還入壁，不敢復出。

translations.literal: Lou Fan wished to shoot him, King Xiang glared eyes berated him, Lou Fan eyes dared not look, hand dared not release, then fled back entered fortifications, dared not come out again.
translations.idiomatic: Lou Fan wanted to shoot him, but King Xiang glared and bellowed at him. Lou Fan couldn't meet his eyes or release his arrow. He fled back into the fortifications and never dared come out again.

sentences.zh: 漢王使人閒問之，乃項王也。

translations.literal: Han king sent people secretly inquire about it, it was King Xiang.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king sent scouts to investigate secretly, and they discovered it was King Xiang himself.

sentences.zh: 漢王大驚。

translations.literal: Han king greatly astonished.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king was greatly shocked.

sentences.zh: 於是項王乃即漢王相與臨廣武閒而語。

translations.literal: Thereupon King Xiang then approached the Han king and together faced Guangwu gap and spoke.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then approached the Han king and they spoke face-to-face across the Guangwu gap.

sentences.zh: 漢王數之，項王怒，欲一戰。

translations.literal: Han king enumerated them, King Xiang angered, wished one battle.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king listed his grievances. King Xiang was furious and wanted to fight a decisive battle.

sentences.zh: 漢王不聽，項王伏弩射中漢王。

translations.literal: Han king did not listen, King Xiang hid crossbow shot hit Han king.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king wouldn't listen. King Xiang hid himself and shot the Han king with a crossbow.

sentences.zh: 漢王傷，走入成皋。

translations.literal: Han king wounded, fled entered Chenggao.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king was wounded and fled back into Chenggao.

translations.literal: Chu and Han had long confronted each other with no decision. Young men suffered from military service. The old and weak were exhausted from transporting grain. King Xiang said to Han King: 'The world has been in turmoil for several years, only because of us two. I wish to challenge Han King to decide the victor. Do not vainly make the world's people and their fathers and sons suffer.' Han King smiled and declined, saying: 'I would rather fight with wits, I cannot fight with strength.' King Xiang ordered brave warriors to go out and challenge. Han had a skilled horse archer named Lou Fan. Chu challenged three rounds. Lou Fan each time shot and killed them. King Xiang was greatly angered. He then personally donned armor, held a halberd, and challenged. Lou Fan wished to shoot him. King Xiang glared with his eyes and berated him. Lou Fan's eyes did not dare look, his hand did not dare release. He then fled back and entered the fortifications, not daring to come out again. Han King sent people to secretly ask him. It was King Xiang. Han King was greatly shocked. Therefore King Xiang then approached Han King and they mutually faced each other between Guangwu and spoke. Han King berated him. King Xiang was angered and wished for one battle. Han King did not listen. King Xiang hid and shot Han King with a crossbow. Han King was wounded and fled into Chenggao.

sentences.zh: 項王聞淮陰侯已舉河北，破齊、趙，且欲擊楚，乃使龍且往擊之。

translations.literal: King Xiang heard Marquis of Huaiyin already raised north of Yellow River, defeated Qi, Zhao, moreover wished to attack Chu, then sent Long Ju to go attack him.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang heard that Han Xin had already raised troops north of the Yellow River, defeated Qi and Zhao, and was about to attack Chu. He sent Long Ju to fight him.

sentences.zh: 淮陰侯與戰，騎將灌嬰擊之，大破楚軍，殺龍且。

translations.literal: Marquis of Huaiyin fought with him, cavalry general Guan Ying attacked them, greatly defeated Chu army, killed Long Ju.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin fought him. His cavalry commander Guan Ying attacked, crushing the Chu army and killing Long Ju.

sentences.zh: 韓信因自立為齊王。

translations.literal: Han Xin thus self-established as King of Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin then proclaimed himself King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 項王聞龍且軍破，則恐，使盱臺人武涉往說淮陰侯。

translations.literal: King Xiang heard Long Ju army defeated, then feared, sent Xutai person Wu She to go persuade Marquis of Huaiyin.
translations.idiomatic: When King Xiang heard that Long Ju's army was defeated, he became fearful and sent Wu She of Xutai to persuade Han Xin.

sentences.zh: 淮陰侯弗聽。

translations.literal: Marquis of Huaiyin did not listen.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin would not listen.

sentences.zh: 是時，彭越復反，下梁地，絕楚糧。

translations.literal: At this time, Peng Yue again rebelled, conquered Liang territory, cut off Chu grain.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Peng Yue rebelled again, conquered Liang territory, and cut off Chu's supplies.

sentences.zh: 項王乃謂海春侯大司馬曹咎等曰：「謹守成皋，則漢欲挑戰，慎勿與戰，毋令得東而已。

translations.literal: King Xiang then told Marquis of Haichun Grand Marshal Cao Jiu and others: 'Carefully defend Chenggao, if Han wishes to challenge, carefully do not fight with them, do not allow them to go east.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then told Cao Jiu, Grand Marshal and Marquis of Haichun, and the others: 'Defend Chenggao carefully. If Han wants to challenge you, don't fight them under any circumstances. Just don't let them advance eastward.'

sentences.zh: 我十五日必誅彭越，定梁地，復從將軍。」

translations.literal: I within fifteen days must execute Peng Yue, pacify Liang territory, again follow the general.'
translations.idiomatic: Within fifteen days I will surely execute Peng Yue, pacify Liang territory, and rejoin you generals.'

sentences.zh: 乃東，行擊陳留、外黃。

translations.literal: Then went east, along the way attacked Chenliu, Waihuang.
translations.idiomatic: He then marched east, attacking Chenliu and Waihuang along the way.

translations.literal: King Xiang heard that Marquis Huaiyin had already raised Hebei, broken Qi and Zhao, and moreover wished to strike Chu. He then sent Long Ju to go strike him. Marquis Huaiyin fought with him. Cavalry general Guan Ying struck him. They greatly defeated the Chu army and killed Long Ju. Han Xin took advantage to self-establish as Qi King. King Xiang heard that Long Ju's army was defeated and then feared. He sent the Xutai man Wu She to go persuade Marquis Huaiyin. Marquis Huaiyin did not listen. At this time, Peng Yue again rebelled, took Liang territory, and cut off Chu's grain. King Xiang then said to Lord Haichun, Grand Marshal Cao Jiu, and others: 'Carefully defend Chenggao. If Han wishes to challenge, carefully do not battle with them. Only do not let them get east.' I will certainly execute Peng Yue in fifteen days, pacify Liang territory, and again follow the generals.' He then went east and en route struck Chenliu and Waihuang.

sentences.zh: 外黃不下。

translations.literal: Waihuang did not surrender.
translations.idiomatic: Waihuang refused to surrender.

sentences.zh: 數日，已降，項王怒，悉令男子年十五已上詣城東，欲阬之。

translations.literal: Several days, already surrendered, King Xiang angered, all commanded males age fifteen and above go to city east, wished to bury them alive.
translations.idiomatic: After several days, the city surrendered. But King Xiang was angry and ordered all males fifteen and older to assemble east of the city, intending to bury them alive.

sentences.zh: 外黃令舍人兒年十三，往說項王曰：「彭越彊劫外黃，外黃恐，故且降，待大王。

translations.literal: Waihuang magistrate's attendant boy age thirteen, went to persuade King Xiang: 'Peng Yue forcibly coerced Waihuang, Waihuang feared, therefore temporarily surrendered, awaited Your Majesty.
translations.idiomatic: A thirteen-year-old attendant of the Waihuang magistrate went to persuade King Xiang: 'Peng Yue forcibly coerced Waihuang into submission. The people were afraid, so they surrendered temporarily while waiting for Your Majesty.'

sentences.zh: 大王至，又皆阬之，百姓豈有歸心？

translations.literal: Your Majesty arrives, moreover all bury them alive, the people how have heart to submit?
translations.idiomatic: Now that Your Majesty has arrived, if you bury them all alive, how will the people ever submit to you?

sentences.zh: 從此以東，梁地十餘城皆恐，莫肯下矣。」

translations.literal: From this eastward, Liang territory more than ten cities all fear, none willing to surrender.'
translations.idiomatic: East of here, all the cities in Liang territory—more than ten of them—will be terrified and none will surrender.'

sentences.zh: 項王然其言，乃赦外黃當阬者。

translations.literal: King Xiang approved his words, then pardoned Waihuang those who should be buried alive.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang accepted his advice and pardoned the people of Waihuang who were slated for mass execution.

sentences.zh: 東至睢陽，聞之皆爭下項王。

translations.literal: East to Suiyang, heard of it all competed to surrender to King Xiang.
translations.idiomatic: Word spread east as far as Suiyang, and all the cities competed to surrender to King Xiang.

translations.literal: Waihuang did not submit. After several days, they already surrendered. King Xiang was angered. He ordered all males fifteen years and above to go east of the city, wishing to bury them alive. Waihuang magistrate's retainer, a boy of thirteen, went and persuaded King Xiang, saying: 'Peng Yue forcibly coerced Waihuang. Waihuang feared, therefore temporarily surrendered, waiting for the great king. The great king arrives, and moreover buries them all alive. How will the common people have hearts of allegiance? East from this, all ten more cities in Liang territory will fear. None will be willing to submit.' King Xiang approved his words and then pardoned those in Waihuang who should have been buried alive. Going east to Suiyang, when they heard it, all competed to submit to King Xiang.

sentences.zh: 漢果數挑楚軍戰，楚軍不出。

translations.literal: Han indeed repeatedly provoked Chu army to battle, Chu army did not come out.
translations.idiomatic: As expected, Han repeatedly challenged the Chu army to battle, but the Chu army refused to come out.

sentences.zh: 使人辱之，五六日，大司馬怒，渡兵汜水。

translations.literal: Sent people to insult him, five six days, Grand Marshal angered, crossed troops over Si River.
translations.idiomatic: Han sent men to insult Cao Jiu. After five or six days of this, the Grand Marshal grew furious and crossed his troops over the Si River.

sentences.zh: 士卒半渡，漢擊之，大破楚軍，盡得楚國貨賂。

translations.literal: Soldiers half crossed, Han attacked them, greatly defeated Chu army, completely obtained Chu state treasures.
translations.idiomatic: When half the soldiers had crossed, Han attacked them, crushing the Chu army and seizing all of Chu's treasures.

sentences.zh: 大司馬咎、長史翳、塞王欣皆自剄汜水上。

translations.literal: Grand Marshal Jiu, Senior Secretary E, Sai King Xin all self-slit throats on Si River.
translations.idiomatic: Grand Marshal Cao Jiu, Senior Secretary E, and King Xin of Sai all slit their own throats on the banks of the Si River.

sentences.zh: 大司馬咎者，故蘄獄掾，長史欣亦故櫟陽獄吏，兩人嘗有德於項梁，是以項王信任之。

translations.literal: Grand Marshal Jiu, formerly Qi prison clerk, Senior Secretary Xin also formerly Queyang prison official, two people once had kindness to Xiang Liang, therefore King Xiang trusted them.
translations.idiomatic: Cao Jiu, the Grand Marshal, had formerly been a prison clerk in Qi. Han Xin, the Senior Secretary, had been a prison official in Queyang. Both men had once shown kindness to Xiang Liang, which is why King Xiang trusted them.

sentences.zh: 當是時，項王在睢陽，聞海春侯軍敗，則引兵還。

translations.literal: At this time, King Xiang at Suiyang, heard Marquis of Haichun army defeated, then led troops back.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, King Xiang was at Suiyang. When he heard that the Marquis of Haichun's army was defeated, he led his troops back.

sentences.zh: 漢軍方圍鐘離眛於滎陽東，項王至，漢軍畏楚，盡走險阻。

translations.literal: Han army just besieging Zhongli Mo at Xingyang east, King Xiang arrived, Han army feared Chu, all fled to dangerous places.
translations.idiomatic: The Han army was in the midst of besieging Zhongli Mo east of Xingyang when King Xiang arrived. The Han army feared Chu and all fled to defensive positions.

translations.literal: Han indeed several times provoked the Chu army to battle. The Chu army did not come out. They sent people to insult them. After five or six days, the grand marshal was angered and crossed his troops over the Si River. The soldiers were half crossed when Han struck them. They greatly defeated the Chu army and completely got Chu's state goods and valuables. Grand Marshal Cao Jiu, Chief Clerk Dong Yi, and King Sai Sima Xin all cut their own throats on the Si River. Grand Marshal Cao Jiu had formerly been a Qi prison clerk. Chief Clerk Sima Xin had also formerly been a Queyang prison official. The two had once shown virtue to Xiang Liang, which is why King Xiang trusted them. At this time, King Xiang was at Suiyang. He heard that Lord Haichun's army was defeated and then led his troops back. The Han army was just surrounding Zhongli Mo east of Xingyang. King Xiang arrived. The Han army feared Chu and all fled to dangerous places.

sentences.zh: 是時，漢兵盛食多，項王兵罷食絕。

translations.literal: At this time, Han troops abundant food plentiful, King Xiang troops exhausted food depleted.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Han had abundant troops and plentiful supplies, while King Xiang's troops were exhausted and out of food.

sentences.zh: 漢遣陸賈說項王，請太公，項王弗聽。

translations.literal: Han sent Lu Jia to persuade King Xiang, request Taigong, King Xiang did not listen.
translations.idiomatic: Han sent Lu Jia to negotiate with King Xiang and request the return of Liu Bang's father Taigong, but King Xiang refused.

sentences.zh: 漢王復使侯公往說項王，項王乃與漢約，中分天下，割鴻溝以西者為漢，鴻溝而東者為楚。

translations.literal: Han king again sent Marquis Gong to go persuade King Xiang, King Xiang then with Han agreed, divide the empire in middle, cede Honggou west to Han, Honggou east to Chu.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king then sent Marquis Gong to negotiate with King Xiang. King Xiang agreed to divide the empire with Han, ceding all territory west of the Honggou Canal to Han and keeping everything east for Chu.

sentences.zh: 項王許之，即歸漢王父母妻子。

translations.literal: King Xiang permitted it, immediately returned Han king parents wives children.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang agreed and immediately returned the Han king's parents, wives, and children.

sentences.zh: 軍皆呼萬歲。

translations.literal: Army all called out 'Ten thousand years.'
translations.idiomatic: The entire army shouted 'Long live the emperor!'

sentences.zh: 漢王乃封侯公為平國君。

translations.literal: Han king then enfeoffed Marquis Gong as Lord of Pingguo.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king then enfeoffed Marquis Gong as the Lord of Pingguo.

sentences.zh: 匿弗肯復見。

translations.literal: Hid and refused to see again.
translations.idiomatic: He went into hiding and refused to see anyone again.

sentences.zh: 曰：「此天下辯士，所居傾國，故號為平國君。」

translations.literal: Said: 'This empire's eloquent persuader, wherever he resides overthrows kingdoms, therefore titled Lord of Pingguo.'
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'This man is the empire's most eloquent persuader. Wherever he resides, he can overthrow kingdoms. That's why he's called the Lord of Pingguo.'

sentences.zh: 項王已約，乃引兵解而東歸。

translations.literal: King Xiang having agreed, then led troops withdrew and east returned.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang had agreed to the treaty, so he led his troops in withdrawal and returned east.

translations.literal: At this time, Han's troops were flourishing and had plentiful food. King Xiang's troops were exhausted and their food was cut off. Han sent Lu Jia to persuade King Xiang and request Tai Gong. King Xiang did not listen. Han King again sent Marquis Hou Gong to go persuade King Xiang. King Xiang then agreed with Han to divide the world in the middle, with Honggou west going to Han and Honggou east going to Chu. King Xiang permitted it and immediately returned Han King's parents, wives, and children. The army all called 'ten thousand years.' Han King then enfeoffed Marquis Hou Gong as Lord Pingguo. He hid and was not willing to be seen again. He said: 'This is a world-class eloquent scholar. Wherever he resides, he overthrows the state. Therefore he is titled Lord Pingguo.' King Xiang had already agreed. He then led his troops to withdraw and return east.

sentences.zh: 漢欲西歸，張良、陳平說曰：「漢有天下太半，而諸侯皆附之。

translations.literal: Han wished to west return, Zhang Liang, Chen Ping advised: 'Han has more than half the empire, and all the feudal lords attach to it.
translations.idiomatic: Han was preparing to return west when Zhang Liang and Chen Ping advised: 'Han now controls more than half the empire, and all the feudal lords are allied with us.'

sentences.zh: 楚兵罷食盡，此天亡楚之時也，不如因其機而遂取之。

translations.literal: Chu troops exhausted food depleted, this heaven destroys Chu time, better take advantage of the opportunity and immediately seize it.
translations.idiomatic: Chu's troops are exhausted and out of food. This is heaven's moment to destroy Chu. We should seize this opportunity and conquer them now.'

sentences.zh: 今釋弗擊，此所謂『養虎自遺患』也。」

translations.literal: Now release without attacking, this called 'raise tiger self leave calamity.'
translations.idiomatic: If we let them go now without attacking, this is what they call 'raising a tiger that will bring disaster upon yourself.''

sentences.zh: 漢王聽之。

translations.literal: Han king listened to it.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king heeded their advice.

sentences.zh: 漢五年，漢王乃追項王至陽夏南，止軍，與淮陰侯韓信、建成侯彭越期會而擊楚軍。

translations.literal: Han fifth year, Han king then pursued King Xiang to Yangxia south, stopped army, with Marquis of Huaiyin Han Xin, Marquis of Jiancheng Peng Yue arranged meeting and attacked Chu army.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifth year of Han, the Han king pursued Xiang Yu south to Yangxia. He halted his army and arranged to meet with Han Xin, Marquis of Huaiyin, and Peng Yue, Marquis of Jiancheng, to attack the Chu army together.

sentences.zh: 至固陵，而信、越之兵不會。

translations.literal: Arrived at Guling, but Xin, Yue troops did not meet.
translations.idiomatic: When they reached Guling, Han Xin and Peng Yue's troops failed to arrive for the rendezvous.

sentences.zh: 楚擊漢軍，大破之。

translations.literal: Chu attacked Han army, greatly defeated it.
translations.idiomatic: Chu attacked the Han army and inflicted a major defeat.

sentences.zh: 漢王復入壁，深塹而自守。

translations.literal: Han king again entered fortifications, deepened moats and defended himself.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king retreated back into his fortifications, deepened the moats, and defended himself.

sentences.zh: 謂張子房曰：「諸侯不從約，為之柰何？」

translations.literal: Told Zhang Zifang: 'The feudal lords do not follow the agreement, what to do about it?'
translations.idiomatic: He asked Zhang Liang: 'The feudal lords aren't honoring their agreements. What should we do?'

sentences.zh: 對曰：「楚兵且破，信、越未有分地，其不至固宜。

translations.literal: Replied: 'Chu troops about to be defeated, Xin, Yue not yet have divided land, their not coming is naturally appropriate.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang replied: 'Chu's army is about to be defeated. Han Xin and Peng Yue haven't received their territorial divisions yet. It's only natural they wouldn't come.'

sentences.zh: 君王能與共分天下，今可立致也。

translations.literal: Your Majesty can together with them divide the empire, now can immediately achieve it.
translations.idiomatic: If Your Majesty divides the empire with them, we can achieve victory immediately.'

sentences.zh: 即不能，事未可知也。

translations.literal: If cannot, affairs not yet knowable.
translations.idiomatic: If not, the outcome remains uncertain.'

sentences.zh: 君王能自陳以東傅海，盡與韓信；

translations.literal: Your Majesty can from Chen east extending to sea, all give to Han Xin;
translations.idiomatic: If Your Majesty gives Han Xin all territory from Chen east to the sea;

sentences.zh: 睢陽以北至穀城，以與彭越：使各自為戰，則楚易敗也。」

translations.literal: Suiyang north to Gucheng, to give to Peng Yue: make each fight for themselves, then Chu easily defeated.'
translations.idiomatic: and gives Peng Yue territory from Suiyang north to Gucheng, then each can fight for their own interests and Chu will be easily defeated.'

sentences.zh: 漢王曰：「善。」

translations.literal: Han king said: 'Good.'
translations.idiomatic: The Han king said: 'Excellent.'

sentences.zh: 於是乃發使者告韓信、彭越曰：「并力擊楚。

translations.literal: Thereupon then sent envoys to inform Han Xin, Peng Yue: 'Combine forces to attack Chu.
translations.idiomatic: He then dispatched envoys to Han Xin and Peng Yue: 'Join forces to attack Chu.'

sentences.zh: 楚破，自陳以東傅海與齊王，睢陽以北至穀城與彭相國。」

translations.literal: Chu defeated, from Chen east extending to sea give to King of Qi, Suiyang north to Gucheng give to Prime Minister Peng.'
translations.idiomatic: Once Chu is defeated, give the King of Qi all territory from Chen east to the sea, and give Prime Minister Peng territory from Suiyang north to Gucheng.'

sentences.zh: 使者至，韓信、彭越皆報曰：「請今進兵。」

translations.literal: Envoys arrived, Han Xin, Peng Yue all replied: 'Request now advance troops.'
translations.idiomatic: When the envoys arrived, both Han Xin and Peng Yue replied: 'We request permission to advance immediately.'

sentences.zh: 韓信乃從齊往，劉賈軍從壽春并行，屠城父，至垓下。

translations.literal: Han Xin then from Qi went, Liu Jia army from Shouchun advanced together, massacred Chengfu, arrived at Gaixia.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin marched from Qi, Liu Jia's army advanced from Shouchun alongside him. They massacred the population of Chengfu and arrived at Gaixia.

sentences.zh: 大司馬周殷叛楚，以舒屠六，舉九江兵，隨劉賈、彭越皆會垓下，詣項王。

translations.literal: Grand Marshal Zhou Yin rebelled against Chu, massacred Liu in Shu, raised Jiujiang troops, followed Liu Jia, Peng Yue all met at Gaixia, went to Xiang Yu.
translations.idiomatic: Grand Marshal Zhou Yin defected from Chu, massacred the Liu clan in Shu, raised troops from Jiujiang, and joined Liu Jia and Peng Yue. They all converged at Gaixia to confront Xiang Yu.

translations.literal: Han wished to return west. Zhang Liang and Chen Ping advised, saying: 'Han has more than half the world, and all the feudal lords attach to it. Chu's troops are exhausted and food is exhausted. This is heaven's time to destroy Chu. It is better to take advantage of this opportunity and then take it. Now to release and not strike—this is what is called 'raising a tiger that leaves calamity for oneself.' Han King listened to it. In Han's fifth year, Han King then pursued King Xiang to south of Yangxia. He stopped his army and agreed to meet with Marquis Huaiyin Han Xin and Marquis Jiancheng Peng Yue to strike the Chu army. They arrived at Guling, but Xin and Yue's troops did not assemble. Chu struck the Han army and greatly defeated it. Han King again entered the fortifications, dug deep moats, and defended himself. He said to Zhang Zifang: 'The feudal lords do not follow the agreement. What should I do?' He replied: 'Chu's troops are about to be broken. Xin and Yue do not yet have divided lands. Their not coming is certainly appropriate. If the lord king is able to share and divide the world with them, it can be achieved immediately now. If not able, matters are not yet knowable. If the lord king is able to give from Chen east reaching the sea, completely to Han Xin; From Suiyang north to Gucheng, to give to Peng Yue: make each fight for themselves, then Chu will be easy to defeat.' Han King said: 'Good.' Therefore he then sent envoys to tell Han Xin and Peng Yue: 'Combine your strength to strike Chu. When Chu is broken, from Chen east reaching the sea to give to the Qi King, from Suiyang north to Gucheng to give to Chancellor Peng.' The envoys arrived. Han Xin and Peng Yue all replied: 'We request to advance troops now.' Han Xin then went from Qi. Liu Jia's army went together from Shouchun, slaughtered Chengfu, and arrived at Gaixia. Grand Marshal Zhou Yin rebelled against Chu. With Shu he slaughtered Liu, raised the Jiujiang troops, and followed Liu Jia and Peng Yue. They all assembled at Gaixia and went to King Xiang.

sentences.zh: 項王軍壁垓下，兵少食盡，漢軍及諸侯兵圍之數重。

translations.literal: King Xiang army fortified at Gaixia, troops few food exhausted, Han army and feudal lord troops encircled them several layers.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang's army was fortified at Gaixia. His troops were few and food was exhausted. Han forces and allied armies surrounded him in multiple layers.

sentences.zh: 夜聞漢軍四面皆楚歌，項王乃大驚曰：「漢皆已得楚乎？

translations.literal: Night heard Han army four sides all Chu songs, King Xiang then greatly astonished said: 'Han all already obtained Chu?
translations.idiomatic: That night, Xiang Yu heard Chu songs coming from all four sides of the Han encampment. He was greatly shocked: 'Has Han conquered all of Chu?'

sentences.zh: 是何楚人之多也！」

translations.literal: This what Chu people's many!'
translations.idiomatic: Why are there so many Chu people here!'

sentences.zh: 項王則夜起，飲帳中。

translations.literal: King Xiang then night rose, drank in tent.
translations.idiomatic: That night, Xiang Yu rose and drank in his tent.

sentences.zh: 有美人名虞，常幸從；

translations.literal: Had beautiful woman named Yu, often favored to follow;
translations.idiomatic: He had a beautiful concubine named Yu who always accompanied him;

sentences.zh: 駿馬名騅，常騎之。

translations.literal: Excellent horse named Zhui, often rode it.
translations.idiomatic: and a fine horse named Zhui that he always rode.

sentences.zh: 於是項王乃悲歌慨，自為詩曰：「力拔山兮氣蓋世，時不利兮騅不逝。

translations.literal: Thereupon King Xiang then sorrowful song sighed, self-made poem: 'Strength uproots mountains energy covers world, times unfavorable Zhui not advances.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then sang a sorrowful lament and composed this poem: 'My strength uproots mountains, my spirit surpasses the world. But times are unfavorable, and Zhui cannot advance.'

sentences.zh: 騅不逝兮可柰何，虞兮虞兮柰若何！」

translations.literal: Zhui not advances can do what, Yu Yu can do what!'
translations.idiomatic: Zhui cannot advance—what can I do? Yu, oh Yu—what shall become of you!'

sentences.zh: 歌數闋，美人和之。

translations.literal: Sang several stanzas, beautiful woman harmonized with it.
translations.idiomatic: He sang several verses, and the beautiful woman harmonized with him.

sentences.zh: 項王泣數行下，左右皆泣，莫能仰視。

translations.literal: King Xiang wept several rows down, attendants all wept, none could look up.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang wept until tears flowed in streams. All his attendants wept and could not bear to look at him.

translations.literal: King Xiang's army was fortified at Gaixia. His troops were few and food exhausted. The Han army and feudal lords' troops surrounded it in several layers. At night he heard that on all four sides the Han army was singing Chu songs. King Xiang then was greatly startled and said: 'Has Han already gotten all of Chu? Why are there so many Chu people!' King Xiang then rose at night and drank in his tent. He had a beauty named Yu, whom he constantly favored and who followed him; A fine horse named Zhui, which he constantly rode. Therefore King Xiang then sang a sorrowful and heroic song. He made a poem for himself: 'Strength uproots mountains, vigor covers the world. Time is unfavorable, Zhui will not go. Zhui will not go—what can be done? Yu, Yu—what should I do with you!' He sang several stanzas. The beauty harmonized with him. King Xiang wept several streams of tears. All those on his left and right wept. None could look up.

sentences.zh: 於是項王乃上馬騎，麾下壯士騎從者八百餘人，直夜潰圍南出，馳走。

translations.literal: Thereupon King Xiang then mounted horse, commanded brave warriors horsemen followers eight hundred more people, straight night broke encirclement south went out, galloped fled.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then mounted his horse. With over eight hundred brave horsemen under his command, he broke through the encirclement that very night and galloped south.

sentences.zh: 平明，漢軍乃覺之，令騎將灌嬰以五千騎追之。

translations.literal: Dawn, Han army then discovered it, ordered cavalry general Guan Ying with five thousand horsemen pursue him.
translations.idiomatic: At dawn, the Han army discovered his escape and ordered the cavalry commander Guan Ying to pursue with five thousand horsemen.

sentences.zh: 項王渡淮，騎能屬者百餘人耳。

translations.literal: King Xiang crossed Huai, horsemen able to follow hundred more people only.
translations.idiomatic: After King Xiang crossed the Huai River, only about a hundred horsemen remained with him.

sentences.zh: 項王至陰陵，迷失道，問一田父，田父紿曰「左」。

translations.literal: King Xiang arrived at Yinling, lost way, asked one farmer, farmer deceived said 'left'.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang reached Yinling but lost his way. He asked a farmer for directions, but the farmer deceived him by saying 'go left.'

sentences.zh: 左，乃陷大澤中。

translations.literal: Left, then trapped in great marsh.
translations.idiomatic: Going left led him into a great marsh where he became trapped.

sentences.zh: 以故漢追及之。

translations.literal: Because of this Han pursued and overtook him.
translations.idiomatic: This allowed the Han forces to catch up with him.

sentences.zh: 項王乃復引兵而東，至東城，乃有二十八騎。

translations.literal: King Xiang then again led troops east, arrived at Dongcheng, then had twenty-eight horsemen.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then led his remaining troops east and reached Dongcheng. By then, he had only twenty-eight horsemen left.

sentences.zh: 漢騎追者數千人。

translations.literal: Han horsemen pursuing several thousand.
translations.idiomatic: Several thousand Han horsemen were in pursuit.

sentences.zh: 項王自度不得脫。

translations.literal: King Xiang self-assessed could not escape.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang realized he could not escape.

sentences.zh: 謂其騎曰：「吾起兵至今八歲矣，身七十餘戰，所當者破，所擊者服，未嘗敗北，遂霸有天下。

translations.literal: Told his horsemen: 'I raised troops until now eight years, personally seventy more battles, those confronted broken, those attacked submitted, never defeated fled, thus dominated possessed the world.
translations.idiomatic: He told his horsemen: 'I have been fighting for eight years now. I have personally fought over seventy battles. Those I confronted were broken, those I attacked submitted. I never suffered defeat and fled. Thus I came to dominate the world.'

sentences.zh: 然今卒困於此，此天之亡我，非戰之罪也。

translations.literal: Yet now finally trapped here, this heaven destroys me, not battle's fault.
translations.idiomatic: Yet now I am finally trapped here. This is heaven's will to destroy me, not a fault of my generalship.'

sentences.zh: 今日固決死，願為諸君快戰，必三勝之，為諸君潰圍，斬將，刈旗，令諸君知天亡我，非戰之罪也。」

translations.literal: Today certainly resolved to die, wish for you gentlemen satisfying battle, must three times defeat them, for you gentlemen break encirclement, behead generals, cut banners, cause you gentlemen know heaven destroys me, not battle's fault.'
translations.idiomatic: Today I am resolved to die. I wish to fight one satisfying battle for you gentlemen. I will surely defeat them three times, break their encirclement for you, behead their generals, and cut down their banners. This will show you that heaven destroys me, not poor generalship.''

sentences.zh: 乃分其騎以為四隊，四向。

translations.literal: Then divided his horsemen into four squads, four directions.
translations.idiomatic: He then divided his horsemen into four squads facing four directions.

sentences.zh: 漢軍圍之數重。

translations.literal: Han army encircled them several layers.
translations.idiomatic: The Han army encircled them in multiple layers.

sentences.zh: 項王謂其騎曰：「吾為公取彼一將。」

translations.literal: King Xiang told his horsemen: 'I for you take that one general.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang told his horsemen: 'I will get you that general.'

sentences.zh: 令四面騎馳下，期山東為三處。

translations.literal: Commanded four sides horsemen gallop down, agreed east of mountain as three places.
translations.idiomatic: He commanded the horsemen on all four sides to charge down and agreed to rally at three places east of the mountain.

sentences.zh: 於是項王大呼馳下，漢軍皆披靡，遂斬漢一將。

translations.literal: Thereupon King Xiang great shout galloped down, Han army all scattered, then beheaded Han one general.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then shouted loudly and charged down. The Han army scattered in all directions, and he beheaded one of their generals.

sentences.zh: 是時，赤泉侯為騎將，追項王，項王瞋目而叱之，赤泉侯人馬俱驚，辟易數里與其騎會為三處。

translations.literal: At this time, Chi Quan Hou was cavalry general, pursued King Xiang, King Xiang glared eyes and berated him, Chi Quan Hou man horse both frightened, retreated several li joined with his horsemen became three places.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Chi Quan Hou was the cavalry general pursuing Xiang Yu. Xiang Yu glared and bellowed at him, frightening both man and horse. Chi Quan Hou retreated several li and rallied with his horsemen at the three designated places.

sentences.zh: 漢軍不知項王所在，乃分軍為三，復圍之。

translations.literal: Han army did not know King Xiang location, then divided army into three, again encircled him.
translations.idiomatic: The Han army didn't know where Xiang Yu was, so they divided into three forces and encircled him again.

sentences.zh: 項王乃馳，復斬漢一都尉，殺數十百人，復聚其騎，亡其兩騎耳。

translations.literal: King Xiang then galloped, again beheaded Han one colonel, killed several ten hundred people, again gathered his horsemen, lost his two horsemen only.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu then charged again, beheading another Han colonel and killing several hundred men. He rallied his horsemen, having lost only two of them.

sentences.zh: 乃謂其騎曰：「何如？」

translations.literal: Then told his horsemen: 'How is it?'
translations.idiomatic: He then asked his horsemen: 'How did I do?'

sentences.zh: 騎皆伏曰：「如大王言。」

translations.literal: Horsemen all submitted said: 'As Your Majesty said.'
translations.idiomatic: The horsemen all bowed and said: 'As Your Majesty said.'

translations.literal: Therefore King Xiang then mounted his horse. His commanded brave warriors, with over eight hundred riders following, straight through the night broke the encirclement and went south out, galloping in flight. At dawn, the Han army then became aware and ordered cavalry general Guan Ying to pursue him with five thousand riders. King Xiang crossed the Huai. The riders able to follow were only over one hundred people. King Xiang arrived at Yinling. He lost his way and asked a farmer. The farmer deceived him and said 'left'. He went left and then fell into a great marsh. Therefore Han pursued and caught him. King Xiang then again led his troops east. He arrived at Dongcheng and then had twenty-eight riders. The Han riders pursuing were several thousand people. King Xiang measured himself and knew he could not escape. He said to his riders: 'I have raised troops for eight years until now. I have personally fought over seventy battles. Those I faced were broken. Those I struck submitted. I have never been defeated and fled. I then became hegemon and possessed the world. Yet now I am finally trapped here. This is heaven destroying me, not the crime of battle. Today I certainly decide on death. I wish to fight a satisfying battle for you various lords. I must achieve three victories, break the encirclement for you various lords, behead generals, cut banners, and make you various lords know that heaven destroys me, not the crime of battle.' He then divided his riders into four teams facing four directions. The Han army surrounded it in several layers. King Xiang said to his riders: 'I will take one of their generals for you.' He ordered the riders on all four sides to gallop down and agreed to meet east of the mountain at three places. Therefore King Xiang gave a great shout and galloped down. The Han army all scattered. He then beheaded one Han general. At this time, Lord Chiquan was the cavalry general pursuing King Xiang. King Xiang glared with his eyes and berated him. Lord Chiquan, both person and horse, were startled. He retreated several li and assembled with his riders at three places. The Han army did not know King Xiang's location. They then divided their army into three and again surrounded them. King Xiang then galloped. He again beheaded one Han commandery captain, killed several dozen people, again gathered his riders. He had only lost two riders. He then said to his riders: 'How is it?' The riders all submitted and said: 'As the great king said.'

sentences.zh: 於是項王乃欲東渡烏江。

translations.literal: Thereupon King Xiang then wished east cross Wujiang.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then wanted to cross the Wujiang River eastward.

sentences.zh: 烏江亭長檥船待，謂項王曰：「江東雖小，地方千里，眾數十萬人，亦足王也。

translations.literal: Wujiang pavilion chief moored boat awaited, told King Xiang: 'Jiangdong though small, territory thousand li, people several ten ten thousand, also sufficient to be king.
translations.idiomatic: The Wujiang ferry master had moored his boat and was waiting. He told Xiang Yu: 'Although Jiangdong is small, it covers a thousand li of territory and has hundreds of thousands of people. It is sufficient for you to become king again.'

sentences.zh: 願大王急渡。

translations.literal: Wish Your Majesty urgently cross.
translations.idiomatic: I urge Your Majesty to cross quickly.'

sentences.zh: 今獨臣有船，漢軍至，無以渡。」

translations.literal: Now only minister has boat, Han army arrives, no way to cross.'
translations.idiomatic: Only I have a boat here. When the Han army arrives, there will be no way to cross.''

sentences.zh: 項王笑曰：「天之亡我，我何渡為！

translations.literal: King Xiang laughed said: 'Heaven destroys me, I why cross!
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang laughed: 'Heaven is destroying me. Why should I cross?'

sentences.zh: 且籍與江東子弟八千人渡江而西，今無一人還，縱江東父兄憐而王我，我何面目見之？

translations.literal: Moreover Ji with Jiangdong youths eight thousand crossed river west, now not one person returns, even if Jiangdong fathers brothers pity and king me, I what face see them?
translations.idiomatic: Besides, I crossed the river west with eight thousand youths from Jiangdong. Now not a single one returns. Even if the elders of Jiangdong pity me and make me king again, how could I face them?'

sentences.zh: 縱彼不言，籍獨不愧於心乎？」

translations.literal: Even if they do not speak, Ji alone not ashamed in heart?'
translations.idiomatic: Even if they don't say anything, wouldn't I feel ashamed in my own heart?''

sentences.zh: 乃謂亭長曰：「吾知公長者。

translations.literal: Then told pavilion chief: 'I know you worthy gentleman.
translations.idiomatic: He then told the ferry master: 'I know you are a worthy gentleman.'

sentences.zh: 吾騎此馬五歲，所當無敵，嘗一日行千里，不忍殺之，以賜公。」

translations.literal: I rode this horse five years, those confronted invincible, once one day traveled thousand li, cannot bear kill it, to bestow you.'
translations.idiomatic: I have ridden this horse for five years. It was invincible in battle and once traveled a thousand li in a single day. I cannot bear to kill it, so I give it to you.''

sentences.zh: 乃令騎皆下馬步行，持短兵接戰。

translations.literal: Then ordered horsemen all dismount walk, hold short weapons engage battle.
translations.idiomatic: He then ordered all his horsemen to dismount and fight on foot with short weapons.

sentences.zh: 獨籍所殺漢軍數百人。

translations.literal: Alone Ji killed Han army several hundred people.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu alone killed several hundred Han soldiers.

sentences.zh: 項王身亦被十餘創。

translations.literal: King Xiang body also suffered ten more wounds.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang himself suffered more than ten wounds.

sentences.zh: 顧見漢騎司馬呂馬童，曰：「若非吾故人乎？」

translations.literal: Looked back saw Han cavalry commander Lu Matong, said: 'You not my old friend?'
translations.idiomatic: Looking back, he saw the Han cavalry commander Lu Matong and said: 'Aren't you my old friend?'

sentences.zh: 馬童面之，指王翳曰：「此項王也。」

translations.literal: Matong faced him, pointed to Wang Yi said: 'This is King Xiang.'
translations.idiomatic: Lu Matong faced him and pointed to Wang Yi, saying: 'This is King Xiang.'

sentences.zh: 項王乃曰：「吾聞漢購我頭千金，邑萬戶，吾為若德。」

translations.literal: King Xiang then said: 'I heard Han offers thousand gold for my head, fief ten thousand households, I for you kindness.'
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang then said: 'I heard Han offers a thousand pieces of gold and a fief of ten thousand households for my head. I will do you this favor.''

sentences.zh: 乃自刎而死。

translations.literal: Then self-slit throat died.
translations.idiomatic: He then slit his own throat and died.

sentences.zh: 王翳取其頭，餘騎相蹂踐爭項王，相殺者數十人。

translations.literal: Wang Yi took his head, remaining horsemen mutually trampled contended for King Xiang, those who killed each other several ten people.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Yi took his head. The remaining horsemen trampled each other in their struggle for Xiang Yu's body, killing dozens of their own comrades.

sentences.zh: 最其後，郎中騎楊喜，騎司馬呂馬童，郎中呂勝、楊武各得其一體。

translations.literal: Last of all, Palace Attendant Rider Yang Xi, Cavalry Commander Lu Matong, Palace Attendant Lu Sheng, Yang Wu each obtained one part of his body.
translations.idiomatic: Last of all, the Palace Attendant Rider Yang Xi, Cavalry Commander Lu Matong, Palace Attendant Lu Sheng, and Yang Wu each took one part of his body.

sentences.zh: 五人共會其體，皆是。

translations.literal: Five people together assembled his body, all correct.
translations.idiomatic: The five men put his body back together, and it was complete.

sentences.zh: 故分其地為五：封呂馬童為中水侯，封王翳為杜衍侯，封楊喜為赤泉侯，封楊武為吳防侯，封呂勝為涅陽侯。

translations.literal: Therefore divided his territory into five: enfeoffed Lu Matong as Marquis of Zhongshui, enfeoffed Wang Yi as Marquis of Duyan, enfeoffed Yang Xi as Marquis of Chiquan, enfeoffed Yang Wu as Marquis of Wufang, enfeoffed Lu Sheng as Marquis of Neyang.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore his territory was divided into five parts: Lu Matong was enfeoffed as Marquis of Zhongshui, Wang Yi as Marquis of Duyan, Yang Xi as Marquis of Chiquan, Yang Wu as Marquis of Wufang, and Lu Sheng as Marquis of Neyang.

translations.literal: Therefore King Xiang then wished to cross east over the Wujiang. The Wujiang pavilion chief moored his boat and waited. He said to King Xiang: 'Though Jiangdong is small, its territory is a thousand li. Its multitude is several hundred thousand people. It is also sufficient to be king.' I wish the great king to urgently cross. Now only your minister has a boat. When the Han army arrives, there will be nothing to cross with.' King Xiang laughed and said: 'Heaven destroys me. Why should I cross! Moreover, I, Ji, crossed the river west with eight thousand Jiangdong sons. Now not one returns. Even if the Jiangdong fathers and elders pity me and make me king, what face would I have to see them? Even if they do not speak, would I, Ji, alone not be ashamed in my heart?' He then said to the pavilion chief: 'I know you are an elder. I have ridden this horse for five years. Those it faced had no enemy. Once it traveled a thousand li in one day. I cannot bear to kill it. I bestow it to you.' He then ordered all the riders to dismount and walk, holding short weapons for close battle. Alone, what I, Ji, killed were several hundred Han soldiers. King Xiang's body also suffered more than ten wounds. He looked back and saw the Han cavalry adjutant Lu Matong. He said: 'Are you not my old friend?' Matong faced him and pointed to Wang Yi, saying: 'This is King Xiang.' King Xiang then said: 'I heard Han offers a thousand gold for my head and a fief of ten thousand households. I will show you virtue.' He then cut his own throat and died. Wang Yi took his head. The remaining riders mutually trampled and contended for King Xiang. Those who mutually killed were several dozen people. Finally, the court gentleman rider Yang Xi, cavalry adjutant Lu Matong, court gentleman Lu Sheng, and Yang Wu each got one part of his body. The five people together assembled his body. It was all correct. Therefore they divided his lands into five: enfeoffed Lu Matong as Lord Zhongshui, enfeoffed Wang Yi as Lord Duyan, enfeoffed Yang Xi as Lord Chiquan, enfeoffed Yang Wu as Lord Wufang, enfeoffed Lu Sheng as Lord Nieyang.

sentences.zh: 項王已死，楚地皆降漢，獨魯不下。

translations.literal: King Xiang already dead, Chu territories all surrendered to Han, only Lu did not submit.
translations.idiomatic: After King Xiang's death, all Chu territories surrendered to Han, except for Lu which refused to submit.

sentences.zh: 漢乃引天下兵欲屠之，為其守禮義，為主死節，乃持項王頭視魯，魯父兄乃降。

translations.literal: Han then led world troops wished to massacre them, because they observed ritual propriety, died for their lord with integrity, then held King Xiang head showed to Lu, Lu fathers brothers then surrendered.
translations.idiomatic: Han then led troops from throughout the empire intending to massacre Lu. But learning that the people observed ritual propriety and died for their lord with integrity, he had Xiang Yu's head displayed to Lu. The elders of Lu then surrendered.

sentences.zh: 始，楚懷王初封項籍為魯公，及其死，魯最後下，故以魯公禮葬項王穀城。

translations.literal: Originally, Chu King Huai initially enfeoffed Xiang Ji as Duke of Lu, and when he died, Lu last submitted, therefore with Duke of Lu rites buried King Xiang at Gucheng.
translations.idiomatic: Originally, King Huai of Chu had enfeoffed Xiang Yu as Duke of Lu. Since Lu was the last to submit after his death, he was buried at Gucheng with the rites of a duke of Lu.

sentences.zh: 漢王為發哀，泣之而去。

translations.literal: Han king for him issued mourning, wept for him and left.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king held a mourning ceremony for him, wept, and then departed.

translations.literal: King Xiang was already dead. All Chu lands surrendered to Han. Only Lu did not submit. Han then led the world's troops and wished to slaughter them. Because they guarded rites and righteousness, dying in loyalty for their lord, they then held King Xiang's head and showed it to Lu. Lu's fathers and elders then surrendered. In the beginning, King Huai of Chu initially enfeoffed Xiang Ji as Duke of Lu. When he died, Lu submitted last. Therefore they buried King Xiang at Gucheng with the rites of a Duke of Lu. Han King issued mourning for him, wept, and left.

sentences.zh: 諸項氏枝屬，漢王皆不誅。

translations.literal: All Xiang clan branches and relatives, Han king all did not execute.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king spared all the branches and relatives of the Xiang clan.

sentences.zh: 乃封項伯為射陽侯。

translations.literal: Then enfeoffed Xiang Bo as Marquis of Sheyang.
translations.idiomatic: He then enfeoffed Xiang Bo as the Marquis of Sheyang.

sentences.zh: 桃侯、平皋侯、玄武侯皆項氏，賜姓劉。

translations.literal: Marquis of Tao, Marquis of Pinggao, Marquis of Xuanwu all Xiang clan, granted surname Liu.
translations.idiomatic: The Marquis of Tao, Marquis of Pinggao, and Marquis of Xuanwu were all of the Xiang clan. They were granted the surname Liu.

translations.literal: All the various Xiang clan branches and relatives, Han King did not execute. He then enfeoffed Xiang Bo as Lord Sheyang. Lord Tao, Lord Pinggao, and Lord Xuanwu were all of the Xiang clan. They were granted the surname Liu.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：吾聞之周生曰「舜目蓋重瞳子」，又聞項羽亦重瞳子。

translations.literal: Grand Historian said: I heard from Zhou Sheng: 'Shun's eyes probably had double pupils,' also heard Xiang Yu also had double pupils.
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: I heard from Zhou Sheng that Shun's eyes had double pupils. I also heard that Xiang Yu had double pupils.

sentences.zh: 羽豈其苗裔邪？

translations.literal: Yu could it be his descendant?
translations.idiomatic: Could Xiang Yu have been a descendant of Shun?

sentences.zh: 何興之暴也！

translations.literal: What rise's violence!
translations.idiomatic: How violent was his rise to power!

sentences.zh: 夫秦失其政，陳涉首難，豪傑蜂起，相與并爭，不可勝數。

translations.literal: Indeed Qin lost its governance, Chen She first made difficulty, heroes swarmed rise, together contended, cannot count them all.
translations.idiomatic: Indeed, Qin lost its mandate to rule. Chen She started the rebellion, and heroes rose up in swarms, contending with each other beyond counting.

sentences.zh: 然羽非有尺寸，乘執起隴畝之中，三年，遂將五諸侯滅秦，分裂天下，而封王侯，政由羽出，號為「霸王」，位雖不終，近古以來未嘗有也。

translations.literal: Yet Yu did not have inch of land, rose from among the fields and ditches, three years, then led five feudal lords destroyed Qin, divided the world, and enfeoffed kings and marquises, government came from Yu, titled 'Hegemon King', position though not lasting, since near ancient times never had.
translations.idiomatic: Yet Xiang Yu had no territory of his own. He rose from among the fields and ditches, and in three years led the five allied lords to destroy Qin, divide the empire, and enfeoff kings and marquises. Government came from Xiang Yu, who was titled 'Hegemon King.' Though his position did not last, since near ancient times there has never been another like him.

sentences.zh: 及羽背關懷楚，放逐義帝而自立，怨王侯叛己，難矣。

translations.literal: When Yu betrayed the alliance cherished Chu, banished Righteous Emperor and self-established, resented kings marquises rebelled against him, difficult.
translations.idiomatic: When Xiang Yu betrayed the alliance and cherished Chu, banished the Righteous Emperor and established himself, he resented the kings and marquises who rebelled against him. This was difficult.

sentences.zh: 自矜功伐，奮其私智而不師古，謂霸王之業，欲以力征經營天下，五年卒亡其國，身死東城，尚不覺寤而不自責，過矣。

translations.literal: Self-praised achievements exploits, exerted his private wisdom without taking ancient as teacher, considered hegemon king enterprise, wished with force conquest manage the world, five years finally lost his kingdom, body died Dongcheng, still not awakened and did not self-blame, wrong.
translations.idiomatic: He prided himself on his achievements and exerted his personal wisdom without learning from the ancients. He considered the enterprise of a hegemon king and wanted to conquer and manage the world by force. In five years he finally lost his kingdom and died at Dongcheng, yet he still did not awaken and blame himself. This was wrong.

sentences.zh: 乃引「天亡我，非用兵之罪也」，豈不謬哉！

translations.literal: Then cited 'Heaven destroyed me, not use troops' fault,' how not mistaken!
translations.idiomatic: He then cited 'Heaven destroyed me, not a fault of my generalship.' How mistaken this was!

translations.literal: The Grand Scribe said: I heard from Zhou Sheng that 'Shun's eyes were probably double-pupiled.' I also heard that Xiang Yu was double-pupiled. Was Yu perhaps his descendant? What a fierce rise! Qin lost its governance. Chen She first rebelled. Heroes swarmed and rose. They mutually united and contended. They cannot be counted. Yet Yu had not an inch of land. He rode the plow and rose from the middle of the fields. In three years, he then led the five feudal lords to extinguish Qin, split the world, and enfeoffed kings and marquises. Government came from Yu. He was titled 'Hegemon King.' Though his position did not last, since near ancient times there has never been such. When Yu turned against the passes and longed for Chu, banished the Righteous Emperor and self-established, resented that kings and marquises rebelled against him—it was difficult. He self-boasted of his merits and achievements. He exerted his private wisdom and did not follow the ancients. He considered the hegemon king's enterprise and wished to manage the world with force and conquest. In five years he finally perished his state. His body died at Dongcheng. He still did not become aware and awake, and did not blame himself. It was a mistake. He then cited 'Heaven destroys me, it is not the crime of using troops.' How is this not mistaken!
